HEADLINE: Companies in U.S. Sing Blues As Europe Reprises 50's Hits 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
European copyright protection is expiring on a collector's trove of 1950's jazz, opera and early rock 'n' roll albums, forcing major American record companies to consider deals with bootleg labels and demand new customs barriers.
 Already reeling from a stagnant economy and the illegal but widespread downloading of copyrighted music from the Internet, the recording companies will now face a perfectly legal influx of European recordings of popular works. 
 Copyright protection lasts only 50 years in European Union countries, compared with 95 years in the United States, even if the recordings were originally made and released in America. So recordings made in the early- to mid-1950's -- by figures like Maria Callas, Elvis Presley and Ella Fitzgerald -- are entering the public domain in Europe, opening the way for any European recording company to release albums that had been owned exclusively by particular labels.
Although the distribution of such albums would be limited to Europe in theory, record-store chains and specialty outlets in the United States routinely stock foreign imports. 
Expiring copyrights could mean much cheaper recordings for music lovers, but they do not bode well for major record companies. (These copyrights apply to only the recordings, not the music recorded.) The expected crush of material entering the public domain has already sent one giant company, EMI Classics, into a shotgun marriage with a renegade label that it had long tried to shut down to protect its lucrative Callas discography. The influx also has the American record industry talking about erecting a customs barrier.
"The import of those products would be an act of piracy," said Neil Turkewitz, the executive vice president international of the Recording Industry Association of America, which has strongly advocated for copyright protections. "The industry is regretful that these absolutely piratical products are being released." 
The industry association is trying to persuade European Union countries to extend copyright terms. Meanwhile, Mr. Turkewitz said, "we will try to get these products blocked," arguing that customs agents "have the authority to seize these European recordings even in the absence of an injunction brought by the copyright owners."
Expiring copyrights have already led to voluminous European reissues of such historically important artists as the violinist Jascha Heifetz and the jazz cornetist Bix Beiderbecke. But the recordings of the 50's are viewed as being of another order. 
That was the era when recording techniques took a quantum leap and when the long-playing record came into its own and was embraced by the public. Even monaural records from the period, before stereophonic sound, are prized today by classical and jazz audiophiles. Artistically, the decade coincided with the golden years of opera legends like Renata Tebaldi; the birth of rock heralded by recordings of Little Richard, Chuck Berry and Presley; and enormous outbursts of creativity from seminal jazz figures like Thelonious Monk and Miles Davis. "That decade of recording transformed music and how the public consumes music," Mr. Turkewitz said.
That was also the great decade of Callas, who was under exclusive contract to EMI. The looming expiration of copyright on EMI's extensive Callas selections compelled that London-based company to form an alliance with a former enemy. 
EMI Classics (formerly Angel Records) has been the official keeper of the Callas discography since 1953, when Callas, the Greek soprano, was 29 and made her first recordings for the company. Over the years, EMI has contended with independent labels that released unauthorized Callas recordings, mostly taken from pirated live performances. In the late 1990's, the bane of EMI's existence was a Milan-based independent called Diva, the largest producer of the unofficial recordings. (A lawyer for Diva, Kriton Metaxopoulos, said that Diva never released Callas recordings without the approval of her heirs.)
But last year, with the support of the Callas estate in Athens, EMI made a deal with Diva, which two years ago reconstituted itself as Marcal Records (for Maria Callas) and moved its offices to the Virgin Islands for tax purposes. In November EMI released a new batch of Callas recordings, including four complete live operas and five CD's of live concerts and rehearsals. The source for these was Marcal. 
The strategy would seem to be, if you can't beat 'em, join 'em. Richard Lyttelton, president of classics and jazz for EMI Recorded Music, concedes as much.
"For many years EMI was in opposition to Diva," Mr. Lyttelton said in a recent interview from London. "But there has been an irresistible pull for us to work together." With this deal, as Mr. Lyttelton explained, EMI "wanted to try to legitimize the market" for these live Callas recordings "rather than try to suppress it."
The company hopes that its unconventional deal with Diva may prove to be an indirect way to maintain dominance in the Callas market, which has been crucial to EMI's artistic legacy and its bottom line. Callas recordings, most of them made between 1953 and 1960, account for about 5 percent of sales for EMI's classical division in a typical year, more than for any artist on that division's current roster, said Mark Forlow, vice president of EMI Classics. "It's amazing," Mr. Forlow said. "Those records just keep selling."
In 1997, to commemorate the 20th anniversary of Callas's death at 53, EMI issued the first of three installments of its complete Callas Collection, which included 59 releases, including 31 complete operas, all impressively remastered, intelligently packaged and rich with program notes.
With its new releases, EMI has issued live Callas performances that it was trying to suppress not so long ago, banking that its quality presentation will draw Callas fans and keep them away from cheaper choices. As a further inducement, the new EMI releases are being sold at mid-price. 
This strategy has been tried for years by specialty labels like Mosaic Records, a reissue company that releases critically praised boxed sets of classic jazz recordings. Mosaic recently released a seven-CD set of recordings by Beiderbecke, who died in 1931. But cheap competition from European labels has hurt the profitability of such projects, said Michael Cuscuna, Mosaic's president.
"With the Beiderbecke set, we went to the original metal discs and did the best possible sound transfers," he said. "But a handful of European companies have put out this stuff just dumped off the original 78's. That the recording exists in such an inferior state hurts the music." Mr. Cuscuna said that some European labels simply wait for a reissue to come out in the United States, then copy it and appropriate the photographs. "Yet, consumers still go for the cheaper product," he said. "It's discouraging. We've got to get the major labels to take a stand."
Consumer advocates and champions of access to creative products see many copyright protections as too lengthy, unfair to the public and ultimately stifling to creativity. "When works enter the public domain, the consequence is extraordinary variety and lower costs," said Lawrence Lessig, a professor at Stanford Law School. Professor Lessig appeared before the United States Supreme Court to challenge a 1998 law that extended copyright protection by 20 years, and a decision could come from the court as early as this month. 
The Callas recordings, for example, "will be taken and put into a million different content spheres," he said. "They will be encouraged and sold in ways not done now."
This is all the more true because of the Internet, Professor Lessig added. Once copyrighted works enter the public domain, he said, "a wide range of copies -- high quality and low -- will quickly be available, always and for free." Unlike many record companies, he considers this beneficial. "People ask, 'How could you ever compete with free?' " he said. "Think Perrier or Poland Spring." 
According to Mr. Turkewitz, it is illegal under American copyright law to download material protected in the United States regardless of the legal status of that material in another country. Still, the computer file-sharing programs that are cropping up everywhere make this law difficult to enforce.
Defenders of extended copyright terms, like Mr. Turkewitz, argue that, if anything, American laws are still too lax and that the European laws are woefully inadequate. 
"The public sees icons like Mickey Mouse and thinks that the companies must by now have made their money," he said. But, he added, 9 out of 10 sound recordings lose money. "Very few materials wind up generating the revenues that sustain an entire system," he said. "The amount of money put back into production by the record companies is enormous. It's extremely risk-intensive." 
One example of what EMI faces by the end of this year is that any European label will be able to release a staple of the company's catalog: the incomparable 1953 Callas recording of Puccini's "Tosca" with Giuseppe di Stefano as Cavaradossi and Tito Gobbi as Scarpia, both at their peaks, with the Italian maestro Victor de Sabata conducting.
Callas fans, no doubt, will heatedly debate the artistic merits and the sound restoration on the four new releases of live performances from La Scala on EMI, the most familiar being a 1955 performance of Bellini's "Sonnambula," with Callas in top form and Leonard Bernstein, then 36, conducting. This recording, available over the years on various independent labels, has long been an underground hit.
The stakes for EMI are considerable. 
"Some in the company say we should be throwing roses on the Aegean Sea every year," Mr. Forlow said. "Callas keeps the lights on here."

HEADLINE: A Bad Bet 

 BODY:
Pro-gambling lobbyists across the country cannot believe their good fortune. The worst budgetary outlook in decades has left plenty of desperate state governments once again vulnerable to being snookered by the gambling lobby's alluring "something-for-nothing" sales pitch, the fiscal equivalent of a comped buffet. States should know better by now. Opposing an ill-advised expansion of legalized gambling will be a true test of leadership for governors and state legislators nationwide. 
 States embraced gambling as a fiscal panacea during the last economic slowdown, in the early 1990's. Video poker machines (the industry's crack cocaine) and riverboat casinos spread into such improbable venues as Iowa and South Carolina. 
 It is painfully clear that not every state, and indeed not every county, can sustain its own Las Vegas. People do not fly across the country to gamble in South Dakota saloons, and there is no long-term economic payoff in enticing locals to ante up. The all-too-distressing reality created by gambling's spread is more crime, more addiction and more local businesses being cannibalized. 
In recent years, the drive to expand legalized gambling has lost its momentum. Flusher economic times helped state governments acknowledge that gambling's social costs outweighed whatever windfall could be had in tax revenue. In 1999 the Congressionally appointed National Gambling Impact Study Commission called for a moratorium on the spread of gambling. 
Now budget deficits are back, and so are the pro-gambling lobbyists. From California to Florida and Massachusetts, states are eyeing an expansion of legalized gambling. The gleeful lobbyists portray the issue as a choice between voluntary and involuntary taxes. What they don't add is that this so-called voluntary tax is regressive and saddles communities with unacceptably high social costs. 
The case made for expanding gambling is usually a disingenuous one. It's all about saving venerable horse tracks (by bringing in slot machines), enhancing an existing lottery or helping Indian nations. An army of Washington lobbyists and outside casino operators eager to join with real and imagined tribes has worked hard to transform laws allowing gambling on reservations into a regulatory Trojan horse stuffed with slot machines. 
Among the ensuing absurdities: Indian-owned off-reservation casinos, like the glitzy one the Seneca Nation opened on New Year's Eve in Niagara Falls, N.Y. Casinos already operate on the Canadian side of the falls. 
One rationale for allowing casino gambling in New York State, as in most places, is a rather defensive "If we don't take the wagers, other states will." Courageous leaders must resist this destructive race to the bottom.

HEADLINE: MORGAN RESOLVES DISPUTE ON ENRON 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan Chase announced yesterday that it would receive about $580 million from insurance companies as part of a settlement resolving one of the most contentious disputes touched off by Enron's collapse.
 The settlement is a partial victory for J. P. Morgan, which had sought nearly $1 billion from the insurers and will take a charge of about $400 million to cover the difference. 
 Trying to put a year of corporate scandal behind it, J. P. Morgan also announced the creation of a $900 million reserve to cover the anticipated costs of various lawsuits and settlements. Those include its share of the recent accord reached by the securities industry regarding conflicts of interest and possible resolutions of suits brought by Enron shareholders.
The charge and the additional reserves will cause the bank to post a loss for the quarter just ended. 
The insurance dispute centered on allegations that J. P. Morgan had defrauded insurers, disguising loans to Enron as commodities trades. The insurers had issued bonds guaranteeing the trades, and J. P. Morgan sought to collect on them after Enron filed for bankruptcy protection in December 2001. The insurers balked at paying, saying that they had been misled about the nature of the transactions. J. P. Morgan contended that the insurance companies were aware of the details of the complex deals -- which later drew the scrutiny of Congressional investigators, regulators and shareholders' lawyers -- and sued the insurers early last year. The case had gone to trial and was set to go to the jury yesterday.
Investors had feared that J. P. Morgan would recover none of the $1 billion it sought from the insurers and they greeted the bank's announcements with enthusiasm yesterday, sending the stock up $1.78, or 7.5 percent, to $25.44.
As both sides faced the uncertainty of the outcome of the case, the insurance companies viewed the settlement as a prudent way to avoid larger lawsuits.
"We are very satisfied with the results of this settlement," said Alan Levine, a lawyer at Kronish Lieb Weiner & Hellman in New York who represented the insurance companies. "The economics of the settlement speak for itself."
But for J. P. Morgan, the settlement resolves only one problem for an institution that has been battered by bad loans and a tough business environment. Some critics have said that J. P. Morgan has not taken adequate steps to prepare for more litigation related to Enron and other companies tainted by scandal, and noted that Citigroup announced last week that it would set up a $1.5 billion reserve to cope with litigation and settlements.
J. P. Morgan's revenues have been disappointing for two years, since the merger of J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan, and its stock declined almost 40 percent in 2002. Even without the fallout from Enron, J. P. Morgan's chief executive, William B. Harrison Jr., who helped engineer the giant merger, faces significant challenges because of the plunge in the stock market and in investment banking.
"What you still have is a case of very depressed earnings; I can't imagine a near- or intermediate-term improvement in that," said Stephen Biggar, a bank equity analyst at Standard & Poor's. The company must deal with both risky loans and slow investment banking business, he said. "Unless or until those things improve, I don't see any fundamental improvement."
Nonetheless, the settlement of the dispute with the insurance companies is good news, analysts said, because it eliminates uncertainty about the outcome of a trial that was under way in federal court in Manhattan. 
The insurance companies, including Travelers and Liberty Mutual, said J. P. Morgan participated in fraudulent transactions involving contracts to buy gas by a Jersey Islands entity, Mahonia Ltd. 
The insurance companies, which issued surety bonds to guarantee the delivery of the gas, argued that Mahonia was never intended to receive any gas. Instead, they contended that the gas purchases and subsequent trades really provided a way for J. P. Morgan to lend money to Enron without loans appearing on Enron's balance sheet. 
When Enron filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in late 2001, it ceased to comply with the gas sales contracts. J. P. Morgan sought to compel the insurers to pay on the surety bonds, the insurance companies refused, and the bank sued.
In court last month, the insurance companies introduced an e-mail message by a J. P. Morgan vice chairman, Donald H. Layton, referring to transactions involving Enron as "disguised loans." It was not clear, though, that Mr. Layton was referring specifically to transactions involving Mahonia. J. P. Morgan insisted in court that the insurance companies knew the nature of the transactions involving Enron.
In an e-mail message sent to J. P. Morgan employees on the eve of trial in early December, the bank's general counsel wrote that J. P. Morgan "made no representations to the insurance companies," and that "when they issued the bonds, the insurance companies made little or no inquiry about the facts about which they now say they were misled."
Yesterday, J. P. Morgan executives said the settlement vindicated their argument that the insurers' payment obligations were valid.
"The settlement at the level at which we settled represents, at least from our perspective, recognition of our position that we were in the right," Dina Dublon, J. P. Morgan's chief financial officer, said in a conference call with analysts.
Another financial institution, FleetBoston Financial, also participated in one of the Mahonia transactions and will be covered by the settlement, though its exposure was a fraction of J. P. Morgan's. A spokesman for the bank declined to comment.
J. P. Morgan valued the settlement at $579 million, or 60 percent of the $965 million that it sought. The insurance companies said that the settlement would cost them about $503 million because the amount they will pay will be reduced by the value of their claims against Enron. The settlement values those claims at 13 cents on the dollar. J. P. Morgan executives said they could sell those claims for that amount, and would still receive about $580 million.
The 11 insurers involved in the settlement are the Travelers Casualty and Surety Company and the Travelers Indemnity Company; the St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company; the Continental Casualty Company and the National Fire Insurance Company, both part of the CNA Financial Corporation; the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, part of Allianz; the Safeco Insurance Company; the Federal Insurance Company, part of Chubb; the Hartford Fire Insurance Company, part of Hartford Financial Services; the Lumbermens Mutual Casualty Company, part of Kemper; and the Liberty Mutual Group.
As a result of the settlement and the creation of the reserve, executives at J. P. Morgan said the bank would take a charge of 43 cents a share for the last three months of 2002 and would report a loss in the quarter. Analysts had predicted that J. P. Morgan would report a profit of about 36 cents a share. In the final quarter of 2001, the bank posted a loss of 18 cents a share, citing losses on loans to Argentina and to Enron, among other items.
Bank executives said yesterday that they did not expect the settlement or reserve to have any impact on its future dividend payments, something that investors have been watching closely.
J. P. Morgan had been treating the full $965 million in the Mahonia surety case essentially as a bad loan and will now take a charge against earnings for the $400 million ($260 million after taxes, according to the bank) that it will not receive, as well as a charge for the $900 million reserve ($600 million after taxes). The charges will be applied to the bank's results for the final quarter of 2002.
That is still relatively good news, said David Stumpf, a banking analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "The market was bracing itself for potential total loss on these surety bonds," so the fact that J. P. Morgan is getting nearly $600 million has cheered investors, he said.
The size of the charges that J. P. Morgan was taking for other litigation also reassured markets, even if it was smaller than Citibank's reserve, Mr. Stumpf said. J. P. Morgan executives said the bank's reserve was smaller in part because it must pay a smaller share of a settlement reached by the securities industry in recent weeks regarding conflicts of interest related to research analysts.
By settling the Mahonia dispute, J. P. Morgan avoids the risk of an adverse jury verdict that could be used against it in other shareholder lawsuits. However, evidence on the nature of the Mahonia transactions -- like the internal bank e-mail messages -- will almost certainly be used against it, said William S. Lerach, who represents the lead plaintiff in an Enron shareholder class-action suit that names J. P. Morgan as a defendant.
"The evidence that came out is very favorable to our case," Mr. Lerach said. "It shows clearly that they were disguised loans and it shows clearly that J. P. Morgan characterized them as disguised loans at the top levels of the company. Of course we will use that evidence."

HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Commercial Developer Jumps Into Home Rental

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
Forest City Ratner Companies, known for developing large commercial and hotel projects including the $1 billion MetroTech Center in Brooklyn and the Harlem Center, an $80 million mixed-use project on West 125th Street, is dipping into the Manhattan residential market.
 Construction is expected to be complete in March on a 20-story, 330-unit rental apartment building at 111 Worth Street that extends from Lafayette Street almost to Broadway in the Civic Center neighborhood. It sits on property that had several low-rise structures that were vacant when they were demolished. Rental of studios and one- and two-bedroom apartments is to begin on Jan. 15. Pinnacle Realty, a partner in the venture, will manage the building. 
 Forest City Ratner's only other residential property in the city is Queenswood, two eight-story buildings for low- and moderate-income tenants built in 1980 in Corona, Queens.
"We haven't done anything in Manhattan before because it is very competitive and because of the difficulty finding locations," said Bruce C. Ratner, the firm's president and chief executive. "We built this ourselves and think it was an opportunity that makes economic sense. 
"We are not new to housing," he continued, pointing out that the firm's parent company, Forest City Enterprises, based in Cleveland, has a background in residential development. "The national company owns well over 25,000 housing units."
The Worth Street project, which cost about $120 million, is being financed through state-issued bonds backed by HVB Real Estate, a division of the HVB Group, a bank based in Munich.
Building a condo or cooperative, rather than a rental, was never considered, Mr. Ratner said. "Although we develop land for multi- and single-family homes around the country, we don't actually build for-sale housing to any extent," he said. "It is more volatile." 
Asked about the timing of opening his first Manhattan residential building in a softening rental market, Mr. Ratner said: "It takes many years to develop a project, and this was probably conceived three years ago. We also feel that the Civic Center area has been underbuilt until now, so the long-term outlook is strong." The company has no current plans to develop other residential buildings here, he said.
Many of the 111 Worth Street apartments, even those on lower floors, will have sweeping views of the East and Hudson Rivers, the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges, Foley Square and City Hall through their floor-to-ceiling windows.
The building, designed by Costas Kondylis, is clad in beige brick panels. The configuration of the apartments is straightforward, with kitchens opening loft-style onto living rooms. Kitchens will have granite countertops, stainless-steel appliances and white laminate cabinets. Floors will be oak parquet, and bathrooms will have standard-size tubs and pedestal sinks.
The building will have some unusual amenities. There will be three outdoor spaces, a sky deck on the roof -- where there will be an outdoor shower for sunbathers -- another deck on the 14th-floor setback and a landscaped garden on the second floor, where a four-hole putting green will be installed. Two netted golf driving cages occupying about 300 square feet will sit at right angles to the garden. There will also be fitness and business centers, and a coffee bar. Retail shops, including a Starbucks, will occupy the double-height ground floor.
Rents for studios will start at $1,815, one bedrooms at $2,350 and two bedrooms at $3,995. The most expensive unit, a large two-bedroom with individual terrace, will be $6,750 a month. Tenants will be eligible for $6,000 grants awarded by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to people living in the downtown area for at least two years. 
In exchange for $114 million worth of tax-exempt bonds issued by the New York State Housing Finance Agency, the company is reserving 56 of the 330 units for residents earning incomes no more than 50 percent of the median income for the area, or about $31,400 for a family of four. Another 10 units are set aside for people with incomes no more than 40 percent of area median income, or $25,120 for a family of four.
More than 16,000 people contacted the Settlement Housing Fund, which is administering the selection process, which begins with a lottery to be conducted on Tuesday and the investigation into the qualification of the candidates. "We closed off the applications at 12,000," said Susan Cole, associate director of the fund.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: South Korea: Trade Surplus Rises 

BYLINE:  By Don Kirk (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Shipments of vehicles, semiconductors and electronic equipment pushed South Korea's trade surplus to $10.8 billion in 2002. 
The Ministry of Commerce said Tuesday that exports totaled $162.82 billion, up 8.2 percent from 2001, while imports cost $152.02 billion, up 7.7 percent. The United States was the biggest market, spending $31.4 billion on Korean products, while China ranked second with imports of $22.8 billion. Two-way trade rose sharply in December with exports of $15 billion, up 27.4 percent from December 2001, and imports of $14.46 billion, up 28 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Anxious And Obsessed With Image

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Of all the notes sounded in the collective dream life of movies lately, the most insistent may be a faraway but steady thrum of fear. As we confront the threat of terrorism and the possibility of war at a time of economic uncertainty, which is the wiser course: to grit our teeth and imagine worst-possible scenarios, or to put on a happy face and reaffirm our faith in the future?
 In "Catch Me if You Can," Steven Spielberg, demonstrating his usual intuition into the mood of mass culture, may have distilled those conflicting impulses more deftly than any other filmmaker. Based on a true story, it celebrates a prodigious teenage master of disguise and fraud embodied by none other than that chameleonic man-child, Leonardo DiCaprio. 
 Although the movie is set in the 1960's, its portrait of a brilliant dissembler speaks directly to an obsession with appearances and surfaces that has grown steadily more intense since the decade the movie both enshrines and gently satirizes. Back then, today's endless vocabulary of image manipulation, from Botox to spin doctor, was still in an early stage of codification. 
Variations on the slippery notion of image can be detected in several other of the more acclaimed films released at the end of 2002. "Far From Heaven" is a stylized homage to the 1950's melodramas of Douglas Sirk, with their glamorous surfaces and churning psychological undercurrents. At the same time, it is a reflection on the gap between the stylized artificiality of films from that era and real life as it was led then. Going further, it comments on the gap between hard-line conservative values and public political correctness in which a slip of the tongue can spell political suicide.
"Adaptation" and "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" -- both of which have scripts by 2002's hottest young screenwriter, Charlie Kaufman -- inflect reality with fantasy, leaving it up to the viewer to choose between alternate interpretations of events. Both movies evoke the world as a tricky through-the-looking-glass hall of mirrors. On a soberer level, "The Hours" and "About Schmidt" revolve around angst-ridden middle-class characters (one a retired Middle American insurance executive) searching for meaning and value in their lives.
Martin Scorsese's "Gangs of New York" (in which Mr. DiCaprio appears as a street fighter bent on avenging his father's murder) and Spike Lee's "25th Hour" are steeped in post-9/11 paranoia. Both refer solemnly to the destruction of the World Trade Center, and their hyper-macho stance presumes an environment so consumed by tribal belligerence that there's no room left for gentleness. A variation of that cynicism even runs to the core of the movie musical "Chicago," the prison fantasies of a murderess whose trial becomes a national sensation that makes her a star.
Those are some of the ideas floating around the worthy end-of-the-year movies, 15 of which are listed in order of personal preference. Omitted are the franchise movies like "The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers" and the latest Harry Potter, James Bond and "Star Trek" episodes, and the season's romantic comedies. The selection makes it a point to mention outstanding supporting performances.

'Talk to Her'
No other filmmaker has a more compassionate appreciation of the human comedy than the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar, whose newest film is a wildly inventive celebration of sensitive men and the comatose women they love. The indelible characters include a virginal mama's boy (Javier Camara) who worships an unconscious ballerina (Leonor Watling) and a weepy Argentine journalist (Dario Grandinetti) in love with a female bullfighter (Rosario Flores). As the story twists and turns, the film becomes a transcendently tender soap opera fraught with tragedy and miracles.
PLUSES: In the year's most ravishing film score (by Alberto Iglesias) swatches of symphonic flamenco pivot around a transfixing performance by the Brazilian singer and songwriter Caetano Veloso. A silent, black-and-white movie-within-the-movie cracks a Freudian joke that sends tragicomic shivers through the rest of the film.
MINUSES: Because Mr. Almodovar's sexually ambiguous universe is a world unto itself, those who demand rigid psychological realism might be confounded.

'The Hours'
Michael Cunningham's Pulitzer Prize-winning meditation on Virginia Woolf's novel "Mrs. Dalloway" skips around in time while reflecting on the lasting power of literature, the possibility of suicide and the essential aloneness of the human condition. Nicole Kidman, giving the performance of her career, offers one of the most truthful and unsettling portrayals of mental illness ever filmed. Julianne Moore, as a morose Los Angeles housewife in 1951, and Meryl Streep, as a book editor living in contemporary Greenwich Village, are Woolf's spiritual heirs nagged by profound life-and-death questions.
PLUSES: A furious, thrashing performance by Ed Harris as a poet dying of AIDS and a smaller, scintillating one by Toni Collette as a troubled California housewife lead the list of brilliant supporting performances.
MINUSES: "The Hours" is the furthest thing from a mall movie. Although it avoids morbidity, it is a somber, literary film that might mystify those unfamiliar with Woolf.

'About Schmidt'
Jack Nicholson is Warren Schmidt, a retired insurance executive from Omaha who hits the road in a Winnebago after the sudden death of his wife. A trip to Denver to attend the wedding of his daughter (Hope Davis) becomes a quest for meaning in a life he sees as pointless. Created by the same directing and screenwriting team (Alexander Payne and Jim Taylor) who gave us "Citizen Ruth" and "Election," the movie balances astute satire of Middle American mores with a deep respect for that culture's solidity.
PLUSES: Mr. Nicholson's portrayal of Schmidt, a sad, stooped-over retiree on the verge of old age, is the furthest thing from the flaming, Mephistophelean rebels that have been his specialty, and it stands as one of his two or three greatest screen performances. Kathy Bates has a flashy cameo as the bridegroom's garrulous, randy mother.
MINUSES: Underneath its humor, "About Schmidt" (like "The Hours") conveys a deep current of angst that some may find forbidding.

'Adaptation'
In a fiercely witty comedy that crashes headlong through the looking glass, Nicolas Cage plays identical twins, both screenwriters, of opposite sensibility. One of them is the movie's real-life screenwriter, Charlie Kaufman, frustrated in his attempt to adapt Susan Orlean's book "The Orchid Thief" into a serious film. The other is his phantom twin, Donald, who writes trashy screenplays that sell and scores with women. The movie's crowning joke is to have its last third hijacked by Donald and turned into a ludicrous but oddly touching action-adventure fantasy that culminates in a Florida swamp. Spike Jonze directed "Adaptation" with the same fearlessly zany elan he brought to "Being John Malkovich." Who knew that a movie about writer's block could be so funny?
PLUSES: Mr. Cage, who appears to have put on at least 20 pounds for his dual role, is equally convincing as a shy, self-loathing schlub and his carefree doppelganger. As Ms. Orlean, Meryl Streep gives a refined comic performance that gives the film a perfect twist of lemon. Most impressive is Chris Cooper's portrayal of John Laroche, the eccentric gap-toothed orchid thief whose story Charlie is struggling to tell.
MINUSES: Those who dislike witty intellectual games will find the movie's smart-aleck concepts and twisty plot irritating.

'Far From Heaven'
Todd Haynes's homage to the sudsy melodramas of Douglas Sirk, set in Hartford in 1957, is a politically savvy variation on the vintage Rock Hudson-Jane Wyman weepie "All That Heaven Allows." Julianne Moore is Cathy Whitaker, a magazine-perfect 50's housewife whose world shatters when her husband (Dennis Quaid) begins exploring his homosexuality, and her chaste friendship with an African-American gardener (Dennis Haysbert) makes her a social pariah. If the film's portrait of a repressed, rigidly conformist society has elements of a horror film, it also resonates uncomfortably with today's conservative, image-obsessed cultural climate.
PLUSES: Ms. Moore's Cathy is a luminous period butterfly whose wings are about to be singed, and Mr. Quaid's Frank is a painfully acute study of sexual repression and self-loathing. The movie is almost stolen by Patricia Clarkson's fussy, chatty portrayal of Cathy's solicitous but ultimately poisonous best friend, whose tolerance is stretched beyond its limit.
MINUSES: Those unwilling to make the imaginative connections the film encourages may find it cold, artificial and overly schematic.

'Chicago'
Although it opened on Broadway in 1975, this cynical vaudeville musical set in Prohibition-era Chicago is right in sync with the age of O. J. Simpson and the Menendez Brothers and the MTV diva wars. Renee Zellweger, who recalls the young Shirley MacLaine, and Catherine Zeta-Jones are Roxie Hart and Velma Kelley, homicidal vaudevillians who, promoted by a lawyer (Richard Gere) with the instincts of P. T. Barnum, become tabloid sensations.
PLUSES: Rob Marshall has turned the movie into a sustained rush of energy that lifts off from his Bob Fosse-style choreography and jump-cut editing. The result is the most exciting movie musical since "Cabaret."
MINUSES: Musical-theater purists have a lot to grumble about. The show's hard-edged characters, especially the sinister prison matron (Queen Latifah), have been greatly softened, and one of the finest songs from the hard-edged Kander and Ebb score, "Class," has been eliminated.

'Gangs of New York'
Martin Scorsese's huge, lumbering epic of ethnic warfare on the mean streets of 1860's New York (culminating in the 1863 Civil War Draft Riots, in which much of the city was consumed by fire) is a towering feat of cinematic imagination. The gory, rough-hewn film is carried on the shoulders of its central character, William Cutting, a k a Bill the Butcher (Daniel Day-Lewis), the brutal one-eyed leader of the so-called Nativists battling the Irish immigrants in huge, splashy set pieces in the Five Points neighborhood. The spine of the story follows the rise of Amsterdam Vallon (Leonardo DiCaprio), the son of a slain Irish-American kingpin, who is determined to avenge his father's death at the butcher's hands.
PLUSES: The breadth of its vision makes "Gangs of New York" Mr. Scorsese's "Apocalypse Now" and "Birth of a Nation." The movie forcefully conveys his brutal vision of a nation forged in bloodshed and tribal warfare. Mr. Day-Lewis's Cutting is a Paul Bunyan-size villain.
MINUSES: Subsidiary characters remain out of focus, and subplots are left frustratingly undeveloped. Mr. DiCaprio's dull, blocky Vallon is no match for Mr. Day-Lewis's swashbuckling butcher.

'The Pianist'
Roman Polanski's film about Wladyslaw Szpilman, a Polish-Jewish concert pianist and composer who against all odds survived in the devastated Warsaw ghetto, is a forceful act of remembrance (and perhaps of contrition) from the exiled bad-boy director. The film documents the rapidly tightening grip of the Nazis on the Jews of Warsaw. By sheer luck, Szpilman, played by Adrien Brody, escapes deportation to a death camp. The heart of the film details his desperate, lonely struggle for food, water and shelter in the closing months of World War II.
PLUSES: Mr. Brody's restrained, largely silent performance conveys a mute suffering and fear that are finally beyond words.
MINUSES: The early scenes have a clunky expository feel. As eloquent as Szpilman's silence may be, it also prevents us from getting to know him.

'Catch Me if You Can'
Frank Abagnale Jr., the teenage con man and chameleon who slithers through Steven Spielberg's sophisticated comedy, is the latest and one of the most memorable in the filmmaker's catalog of lost boys. The movie tells the mostly true story of Frank's ascent from teenage runaway to international notoriety as a check forger who successfully impersonates an airline pilot, a doctor and a lawyer before being apprehended by his Javert-like pursuer, Carl Hanratty (Tom Hanks). The movie pokes delicious fun at the swinging 60's, when air travel was sold as sex in the sky.
PLUSES: Leonardo DiCaprio dazzles as the charming criminal prodigy and chip off the slippery block of his father, Frank Sr., a tax-evading Rotarian played to reptilian perfection by Christopher Walken. Martin Sheen and the newcomer Amy Adams have amusing roles as the unctuously pompous father of Frank's fiancee and the perky daughter who is first seen as a nurse with a mouthful of braces.
MINUSES: After zipping brightly along, the movie eventually loses momentum. Twenty minutes of cutting would have helped.

'Antwone Fisher'
The most potent male weepie to come along in years, "Antwone Fisher" is the somewhat fictionalized biography of its screenwriter (played by Derek Luke), who was born in a Cleveland prison and ended up in an orphanage and then in a foster home. As a hotheaded young sailor, he risks being bounced out of the Navy and is sent to a psychiatrist, who unlocks his pain and directs him to search for his family. The directorial debut of Denzel Washington, who also plays the psychiatrist, "Antwone Fisher" is acted with such refinement that you can almost forgive its sentimental excesses.
PLUSES: As a first-time director, Mr. Washington elicits exquisitely reactive performances that match his own screen acting in care and balance, and Mr. Luke's wonderfully natural, understated Antwone stands as the year's most auspicious screen acting debut. The movie includes the most convincing psychotherapy sessions this side of "The Sopranos." Novella Nelson deserves special mention for her ferocious portrayal of Antwone's brutally abusive foster mother, who drills her racial self-hatred into him.
MINUSES: In giving Antwone the perfect, understanding girlfriend and a therapist who becomes a surrogate father, the movie pours on too much syrup.

'Max'
Menno Meyjes's audacious historical fantasy imagines the young Adolf Hitler (Noah Taylor) as an ambitious young painter struggling for recognition amid the desolation of post-World War I Munich. His part-time mentor, the fictional Max Rothman (John Cusack), is an art dealer and avowed modernist who lost an arm in the war but not his spirit. The film, which has an exotic, expressionist visual palette, proposes that Nazism (with the swastika, the uniforms and all the other regalia) originated as the art project of a failed painter.
PLUSES: In portraying a European bon vivant and intellectual, Mr. Cusack makes a big dramatic leap forward. Avoiding turning into a cartoon, Mr. Taylor's Hitler is a thoroughly disagreeable, socially inept creep whose bottled rage and bogus theories of racial purity are coalescing into a monstrous entity.
MINUSES: The movie is largely fantasy and a platform for contemplating the relationship between art and history. The scenes of Max's turbulent personal life (he has a wife, two children and a lover) are so confusingly sketchy they seem almost extraneous.

'Rabbit-Proof Fence'
The movie tells the true story of three Aboriginal girls of mixed blood who escape after being forcibly taken from their community in the Australian outback to a settlement as part of a government campaign to breed out the Aboriginal race. The heart of the movie follows their 1,500-mile journey home on foot, in which they successfully elude their would-be captors. The director Phillip Noyce treats a story that could have been a gruesome manhunt as an inspirational folk tale.
PLUSES: Everlyn Sampi is quietly mesmerizing as the oldest of the three girls and their intrepidly determined and canny leader. The camera drinks in the beauty and the variety of the Australian landscape.
MINUSES: The movie's decision to tell the story as cinematic folk ballad robs it of credibility. Instead of a grueling odyssey, the journey unfolds as a kind of dream.

'Confessions of a Dangerous Mind'
George Clooney's flashy directorial debut (with a screenplay by Charlie Kaufman) relates the autobiography of Chuck Barris, the creepy, leering television impresario who dumped "The Dating Game," "The Newlywed Game" and "The Gong Show" onto television. The movie treats Mr. Barris's claims that he was a C.I.A. agent on assassination duty so skeptically that his contacts (played by Mr. Clooney and Julia Roberts) appear as delusional as the paranoid-schizophrenic phantoms in "A Beautiful Mind."
PLUSES: Sam Rockwell's star-making portrayal of Barris captures his body language and smirking cynicism without pushing too hard.
MINUSES: As a screen character, Mr. Barris has the same freaky sideshow quality as Bob Crane, the "Hogan's Heroes" star and sex fiend portrayed by Greg Kinnear in Paul Schrader's "Auto Focus," which opened earlier in 2002.

'25th Hour'
Like many of Spike Lee's other movies, this harsh portrait of post-9/11 New York City as a paranoid, hypersexual jungle of feuding tribes gives you the feeling of being shouted at by someone reading tabloid headlines an inch away from your face. The first screenplay by David Benioff, who adapted the story from his novel, "25th Hour" follows the last day of freedom for Monty Brogan (Edward Norton), a youngish drug dealer about to serve a seven-year prison sentence. We meet his girlfriend, Naturelle (Rosario Dawson), who may have ratted on him to the feds, and his two oldest friends, Slaughtery (Barry Pepper), a piggy, womanizing bond trader, and Jacob (Philip Seymour Hoffman), a sniveling teacher besotted with an underage student (Anna Paquin).
PLUSES: Mr. Pepper's Wall Street hotshot is the creepiest screen portrait of a wheeler-dealer since "The Boiler Room." The movie's blunt, hard-boiled dialogue sticks like dirt under your fingernails.
MINUSES: Mr. Norton is slightly miscast as a supposed pretty boy terrified of being gang-raped on his first night in prison. The movie wallows in paranoid urban vibes.

'Nicholas Nickleby'
Douglas McGrath's screen adaptation of the Charles Dickens novel plays like a cheery, cartoonish greatest hits, with the mostly British cast giving the characters the robust "Masterpiece Theater" treatment. But the novel is too large to be contained in a movie, even one that runs two hours and 12 minutes. We've barely settled into one set of characters when we're whisked off to meet the group.
PLUSES: Christopher Plummer's evil, slit-eyed Ralph Nickleby, the hero's heartless uncle, is a cunning, hateful villain for all seasons. Jamie Bell's Smike could wring tears from certain stones.
MINUSES: The movie's thinness of texture is matched by Charlie Hunnam's simpering, platinum-haired Nicholas, an anemic male ingenue so smug in his virtue that you almost root for the scheming Uncle Ralph to destroy him.

HEADLINE: Games Nations Play 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
What game does the Bush administration think it's playing in Korea?
That's not a rhetorical question. During the cold war, the U.S. government employed experts in game theory to analyze strategies of nuclear deterrence. Men with Ph.D.'s in economics, like Daniel Ellsberg, wrote background papers with titles like "The Theory and Practice of Blackmail." The intellectual quality of these analyses was impressive, but their main conclusion was simple: Deterrence requires a credible commitment to punish bad behavior and reward good behavior. 
 I know, it sounds obvious. Yet the Bush administration's Korea policy has systematically violated that simple principle. 
 Let's be clear: North Korea's rulers are as nasty as they come. But unless we have a plan to overthrow those rulers, we should ask ourselves what incentives we're giving them.
So put yourself in Kim Jong Il's shoes. The Bush administration has denounced you. It broke off negotiations as soon as it came into office. Last year, though you were no nastier than you had been the year before, George W. Bush declared you part of the "axis of evil." A few months later Mr. Bush called you a "pygmy," saying: "I loathe Kim Jong Il -- I've got a visceral reaction to this guy. . . . They tell me, well we may not need to move too fast, because the financial burdens on people will be so immense if this guy were to topple -- I just don't buy that." 
Moreover, there's every reason to take Mr. Bush's viscera seriously. Under his doctrine of pre-emption, the U.S. can attack countries it thinks might support terrorism, whether or not they have actually done so. And who decides whether we attack? Here's what Mr. Bush says: "You said we're headed to war in Iraq. I don't know why you say that. I'm the person who gets to decide, not you." L'etat, c'est moi. 
So Mr. Bush thinks you're a bad guy -- and that makes you a potential target, no matter what you do.
On the other hand, Mr. Bush hasn't gone after you yet, though you are much closer to developing weapons of mass destruction than Iraq. (You probably already have a couple.) And you ask yourself, why is Saddam Hussein first in line? He's no more a supporter of terrorism than you are: the Bush administration hasn't produced any evidence of a Saddam-Al Qaeda connection. Maybe the administration covets Iraq's oil reserves; but it's also notable that of the three members of the axis of evil, Iraq has by far the weakest military.
So you might be tempted to conclude that the Bush administration is big on denouncing evildoers, but that it can be deterred from actually attacking countries it denounces if it expects them to put up a serious fight. What was it Teddy Roosevelt said? Talk trash but carry a small stick? 
Your own experience seems to confirm that conclusion. Last summer you were caught enriching uranium, which violates the spirit of your 1994 agreement with the Clinton administration. But the Bush administration, though ready to invade Iraq at the slightest hint of a nuclear weapons program, tried to play down the story, and its response -- cutting off shipments of fuel oil -- was no more than a rap on the knuckles. In fact, even now the Bush administration hasn't done what its predecessor did in 1994: send troops to the region and prepare for a military confrontation.
So here's how it probably looks from Pyongyang: 
The Bush administration says you're evil. It won't offer you aid, even if you cancel your nuclear program, because that would be rewarding evil. It won't even promise not to attack you, because it believes it has a mission to destroy evil regimes, whether or not they actually pose any threat to the U.S. But for all its belligerence, the Bush administration seems willing to confront only regimes that are militarily weak.
The incentives for North Korea are clear. There's no point in playing nice -- it will bring neither aid nor security. It needn't worry about American efforts to isolate it economically -- North Korea hardly has any trade except with China, and China isn't cooperating. The best self-preservation strategy for Mr. Kim is to be dangerous. So while America is busy with Iraq, the North Koreans should cook up some plutonium and build themselves some bombs. 
Again: What game does the Bush administration think it's playing?

HEADLINE: Germany Takes Center Stage 

 BODY:
History could hardly have scripted a more highly charged moment for Germany to commence a two-year term on the United Nations Security Council. As Berlin takes its seat this week, the council is moving toward momentous decisions about Iraq. Only a few months ago, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder ran for re-election declaring his firm opposition to war with Iraq. Now, for the good of Germany and the United Nations, he must set aside campaign politics and cast Germany's votes on this critical issue on the merits. 
 Fortuitously, Germany will preside over the council in February, just when the Iraqi issue is likely to reach a decision point, and has been chosen to lead the council's subcommittee monitoring the enforcement of economic sanctions against Baghdad. During the German election campaign Mr. Schroder pledged that German troops would not fight in Iraq, no matter how blatantly Baghdad defied U.N. disarmament requirements, even if the Security Council authorized force. That stance, largely driven by domestic politics, damaged Germany's international standing, especially in Washington. To earn the international respect it seeks, Berlin must adjust its position to unfolding facts, especially to the report that U.N. weapons inspectors will submit to council members late this month. 
 Germany is under no obligation to support an American-led war against Iraq simply because Washington demands German assent, but Berlin should devise a policy flexible enough to back a confrontation with Baghdad if Iraqi defiance leaves the world no choice but to disarm Iraq by force. In recent days there have been encouraging signs that Berlin is trying to adopt a more nimble approach. This week Mr. Schroder declared that Germans "know from experience that sometimes only violence can stop dictators." Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer indicated that depending on the circumstances prevailing at the time of a Security Council vote, Germany might be willing to authorize using force even though it would not contribute its own troops. In case of war, Berlin has also offered to make its airspace and bases available to the United States and other NATO members.
Emphasizing diplomacy over force is reasonable, but must be accompanied by a recognition that diplomacy alone doesn't always work. As the facts come in on Iraq, Germany should base its decisions on the record of Iraqi conduct.

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Democrats Use Job Chart To Try to Skewer Bush

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Call it incomplete, unfair, misleading or even, as White House officials attest, utterly meaningless.
 But as President Bush prepares to announce a proposal next week for deep new tax cuts, House Democrats plan to circulate a mischievous little chart aimed at skewering him on what they say is one of his biggest vulnerabilities, unemployment. 
 The chart, based on standard government statistics, measures the number of jobs created under every president since Harry S. Truman and ranks President Bush as dead last by a wide margin.
Indeed, Mr. Bush seemed to acknowledge implicitly today that he was exposed on the issue when he told reporters at his ranch in Texas about his planned announcement of a tax-cut package to jump-start the economy and couched the cuts as an effort to create employment. "What I'm worried about," he said, "is job creation." 
Politics, like baseball, is often a game of statistics. And statistics are almost certain to be a crucial weapon in the tax-cut battle and Mr. Bush's broader economic policy. But in much the way a cartoonist can stretch a president's nose to make him look shifty, political pugilists can stretch and shape a telling statistic to skewer a victim or airbrush a glossy portrait.
Democrats cite one batch of statistics to show that Mr. Bush's tax cuts help just the rich. Republicans cite other statistics, equally true, to show that the rich pay the biggest share, by far, of income taxes. 
Although President Bill Clinton averaged more than 230,000 new jobs a month in his eight-year tenure, the chart shows, Mr. Bush has averaged a loss of 69,000 jobs a month since he took office. Although every other president is at least slightly above the zero line, Mr. Bush is conspicuously below it.
Government statistics do indeed show that the economy lost 1.5 million jobs in Mr. Bush's years in office. Those same measures would also rank Jimmy Carter as one of the most successful presidents. Yet Mr. Carter presided over calamitous double-digit inflation, a big reason for his landslide defeat to Ronald Reagan in 1980.
"As a measure of economic growth, job creation is as reasonable as anything else," said Joel E. Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan. "The real question, of course, is to what extent it had anything to do with the policies of the administration." 
Neither Democrats nor Republicans worry much about such distinctions, except when it helps their cause. 
"The administration is going around as if they have already won the Super Bowl," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, whose staff came up with the figures. "Their score for away games may be 6 and 2, but their record on home games is 1 and 7."
White House officials quickly dismissed the chart and cited their figures to argue that the economic problems originated under Mr. Clinton.
"It's misleading to the point of being meaningless," the president's press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said. "It ignores the fact that the recession was really begun as a result of events that took place in 2000."
Mr. Fleischer reached for his batch of statistics. The stock market began plunging in March 2000, manufacturing employment started to decline in July 2000, and industrial production began to decline in September 2000.
By Democratic calculations, the economy will have to add 86,000 jobs a month through the end of Mr. Bush's first term in January 2005 before he would even tie President Dwight D. Eisenhower for last place in job creation.
Mr. Bush was the sole president charted on the basis of two years' experience. Every other president was charted for four-year terms.
Mr. Reagan, who also had a slowdown as he took office, had even worse numbers than Mr. Bush in his first two years but then enjoyed six strong years. Mr. Reagan ended his first term with an average monthly job gain of 109,000 and his second term with an average gain of 224,000.
Nor do employment statistics tell the whole story. Mr. Carter's term coincided with an average increase of 218,000 a month. But inflation soared to more than 15 percent and interest rates skyrocketed to nearly 20 percent before the epidemic was controlled.
Democrats also plan to argue that Mr. Bush's proposal for a tax cut is unlikely to be a panacea. They say the employment decline began in April 2001, just as the House was approving his $1.35 trillion tax cut. The Democrats also note that the economy began shedding enormous numbers of jobs soon after Congress approved Mr. Reagan's huge tax reductions in 1981.
"You can manipulate statistics almost anyway you want, but fact is that behind those statistics you have a human problem," Mr. Obey said.
Democrats also plan to go after Mr. Bush for failing to prevent the expiration of federal unemployment benefits for the 750,000 long-term unemployed workers. The benefits expired on Dec. 28. Last month in a radio address, Mr. Bush favored a modest extension of the benefits that would be retroactive, acting only after Congress had left for the year. And House Republican leaders favor a much smaller extension than the Democrats.
White House officials, still energized from Republican Congressional victories in November, brush off the criticism.
"Often, politicians see economic data as being potent while the voters reject it," Mr. Fleischer said. "If it were true, and if voters perceived it as being true, then why didn't they vote against Republicans in November?"

HEADLINE: We Don't Invade Iraq. Then What? 

BYLINE:  By Robert Malley; Robert Malley, Middle East program director at the International Crisis Group, was special assistant to President Bill Clinton for Arab-Israeli affairs from 1998 to 2001.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
For some time now, the debate over Iraq has focused on a potential war and what should follow it. What is striking is how little thought appears to have been given to the other possible outcome, the one the rest of the world continues to push and the Bush administration itself professes to favor: a nonmilitary settlement. In short, all the talk has been about the day after a war. But what about the day after a non-war?
 An invasion still seems likely. But we may witness an Iraqi turnabout -- last-minute compliance with the United Nations Security Council terms in hope of salvaging Saddam Hussein's regime. There may be a pre-emptive coup by Iraqi security officials determined to get rid of Saddam Hussein before the United States gets rid of them. Or we may have to live with an ambiguous situation that drags on for a long time, with neither a smoking gun nor a clean bill of health, because inspections are inconclusive, American allies deem Iraq's threat insufficient to justify a war and Washington concludes that it would be wiser not to go at all than to go it alone. 
 In any case, avoiding war with Iraq does not mean resolving the problem of Iraq. For the past decade, Iraq policy has been caught between those who believed that sanctions and covert action would make the regime go away, and those who believed that time would make the whole issue go away. Thus Iraq today suffers under harsh international sanctions and harsher domestic repression, with intrusive inspections and disturbing uncertainty about its weapons capability. Sanctions leak, to the benefit of their intended target, the Iraqi regime, and they hurt their unintended victims, the Iraqi people. 
The regime's totalitarian power is intact, but the nation's sovereignty is in shambles, with no-flight zones north and south, a quasi-independent Kurdish area and meddling by its neighbors. Indeed, the message conveyed by the Iraqi citizens interviewed in recent weeks by the International Crisis Group is that the situation is so desperate that many now appear ready to accept a war whose destructive impact they risk being the first to suffer. 
Even if Saddam Hussein were ousted, the Iraq problem is unlikely to disappear. Iraq would still have a volatile domestic situation, long-standing border disputes with neighbors, a rivalry with Iran and a drive to acquire nonconventional weapons. 
The responsibility today, especially for those who wish to oppose a conflict, is to think about what will happen if war is avoided. The central pillar of any plan needs to be deterrence, with commitments from American allies -- possibly backed by a Security Council resolution -- for a crushing military response so credible that the regime will understand that any use of weapons of mass destruction, or indeed any threat to its neighbors, would bring its immediate demise. 
A second pillar would be to induce political change in Iraq. The United Nations resolutions adopted after the gulf war demanded that it cease its repression of its citizens. Needless to say, this call has not been heeded. But Iraq is in dire straits. The oil industry operates at nowhere near capacity, roads and water facilities are a shambles, and Iraq's isolation from most of the industrialized world makes paying for improvements impossible. 
The quid pro quo for Iraq's economic reintegration, including international aid, loans for reconstruction projects and the lifting of sanctions, ought to be key domestic reforms: real elections, political pluralism, ethnic rights. 
Ultimately, so long as any concerns remain about the country's intentions regarding weapons of mass destruction, the ban on military goods and the oil-for-food program should be maintained. Other sanctions -- like the one banning technology that has both civilian and military uses -- could gradually be lifted to encourage domestic reform.
In the longer term, a third pillar would be a Persian Gulf regional security system. Elements of this would include commitments from all gulf states (including Iran) to respect the territorial integrity and sovereignty of their neighbors and to give up programs in weapons of mass destruction. These commitments could be monitored by an international presence on the ground. 
The truth is, while Iraq and Iran may have some very bad reasons to want to develop their nonconventional arsenals, they feel they have some pretty good reasons as well -- not least of all, their fear of each other Unless these fears are addressed, any solution is liable to be short lived. 
Failure to offer practical ideas for what should happen if war does not occur will only make war more likely -- either now or when the next crisis is upon us.

HEADLINE: Bush Is Set to Unveil New Economic Policy 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he would detail his proposal to cut taxes and stimulate the economy on Tuesday, and he brushed aside critics who predicted that his plans would primarily benefit the rich.
 "I am worried about those who are unemployed," he told reporters at his ranch near Crawford, Tex. "I think about the overall economy and how best to help those folks who are looking for work." 
 Mr. Bush is expected to propose a package of tax cuts worth as much as $300 billion over 10 years. The package is expected to include a reduction in taxes on corporate dividends, new tax breaks for business and an acceleration of rate reductions that were supposed to phase in over the next several years. 
To deflect criticism that the plan does little to help the poor and the middle class, Mr. Bush is also likely to propose an immediate increase in the child-care tax credit and a more rapid phase-out of the so-called "marriage penalty" for two-income couples.
But Republican lawmakers in Congress are already worried about keeping the estimated cost of all those measures below $300 billion.
A 50 percent reduction in taxes on corporate dividends would alone cost about $150 billion over 10 years, according to estimates by Tax Policy Center, a nonprofit research organization run by the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institution.
An immediate increase in the child-care tax credit, to $1,000 from $600, would cost $99 billion over 10 years. And accelerating all the rate reductions scheduled for 2004 and 2006 would cost an additional $114 billion.
White House officials have let it be known for months that they favor a new round of tax cuts to jolt the economy out of its doldrums, and they had said Mr. Bush would announce a plan sometime in January.
In deciding to go ahead next week, Mr. Bush seemed intent on imprinting his priorities on the new Congress as soon as it convened. But he will be doing so before his new economic team is fully in place to help sell the plan. Stephen Friedman, a former co-chairman at Goldman Sachs, is starting work this week as head of the White House National Economic Council. John W. Snow, the railroad executive Mr. Bush selected to succeed Paul H. O'Neill as Treasury secretary, has yet to be confirmed by the Senate.
But Mr. Bush badly wants to be perceived as doing something about the economy, and administration officials have long been eager to reduce or eliminate dividend taxes altogether.
Unemployment climbed to 6 percent last month, manufacturing has been stagnant and business investment remains weak. There are signs of improvement: the stock market has climbed shakily from what appears to have been a low point in October, and the latest survey of manufacturers, released today, showed an unexpectedly big increase in orders and expectations.
Economists are at best divided about whether a new round of tax cuts will have much impact on the immediate problems. Many of the tax cuts would not reach taxpayers until later in the year or next year. Lowering dividend taxes could push up stock prices, but many economists say it would have little short-term impact on either consumer spending or business investment.
In pressing for his program, Mr. Bush will be treading a fine line between highlighting the urgent need for quick action and providing reassurance that the economy is improving.
"I recognize that there, you know, there are some uncertainties," Mr. Bush said today. "But one thing is certain: that the economy of the United States is strong and resilient. And we must put policies in place to enhance that resiliency and enhance that strength." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SUBJECT: TAXES & TAXATION (93%); TAX LAW (91%); TAX RELIEF (91%); ECONOMIC POLICY (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); TAX INCENTIVES (89%); US REPUBLICAN PARTY (79%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (73%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (73%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (72%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (70%); EMPLOYMENT (70%); CHILD CARE (68%); POLLS & SURVEYS (68%); MARRIAGE (67%) UNITED STATES ECONOMY; TAXATION

HEADLINE: COMMODITIES; 
Price Soars as Oil Inventories Reflect Strike in Venezuela

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices opened the year yesterday with an increase of more than 2 percent, as a month-old Venezuelan strike cut further into American imports and pushed inventories toward a 26-year low.
 The inventory data showed crude oil in storage dropping 3 percent last week, as shipments from Venezuela all but dried up. Analysts had expected a 1 percent dip. 
 In New York, crude oil for February delivery gained 65 cents yesterday, or 2.1 percent, to $31.85.
Michael Rothman, a Merrill Lynch analyst, said American inventory levels were 50 million barrels below normal. "In fact," Mr. Rothman said, "inventories ended 2002 at their lowest level since we began tracking the data in 1984."
Venezuela accounts for about 14 percent of America's imports, but exports have ground to a virtual halt since early December because of a strike aimed at ousting President Hugo Chavez.
The Energy Department said yesterday that its weekly report on crude oil inventories, showed imports slumping by 1.5 million barrels a day. The United States uses 20 million barrels of oil a day, equivalent to one-quarter of world supply.
"It does appear that crude oil imports from Venezuela last week were almost nonexistent," the agency said.
The long disruption to supplies from Venezuela -- at a time when looming conflict with Iraq threatens to upset flows from the Middle East -- has deepened concerns that higher energy costs could derail a tentative recovery. The decline in inventories brought crude oil storage levels close to a 26-year low reached in October, when storms disrupted operations on the Gulf Coast.
Inventories are approaching 270 million barrels, which the National Petroleum Council, an advisory committee to the secretary of energy, says could result in supply problems during a period of strong demand, like a cold winter.
The data showed American demand for oil growing 5 percent in the last four weeks from the period a year ago, despite sluggish economic growth.
The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, dominated by Middle Eastern states, has offered to make up any supply shortfall caused by the Venezuelan strike.
But supplies from the Mideast take six weeks to reach the United States compared with about five days for oil from Venezuela.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Outlook: Up and Down 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
With his visit to Brazil, a radiant President Hugo Chavez assured the world today that he would survive a month-old strike aimed at forcing him from power. But back home, Venezuelans were left to wonder if their country, as they know it, might not. 
 The president's talk may be bravado, but political analysts here and abroad agree that he appears once again to have beaten his way out of a political corner and taken the upper hand against his opposition, whose strike has all but stopped the heartbeat of the Venezuelan economy: the state-owned oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela. 
 Mr. Chavez may not only survive this latest challenge to his presidency, analysts and some of his opponents are beginning to concede, but he may also emerge with new strength, even if his country emerges more polarized and economically hobbled than before. 
"The opposition underestimated President Chavez's determination to stay in power at all costs," said Luis Pacheco, a striking oil executive. "Any other Western leader would have looked at this situation, at the economic and social distress, and would have left office. But Chavez is willing to govern over ruins."
In April, after a brief coup against him, Mr. Chavez said that as a gesture of reconciliation, he would not dismiss oil company executives accused of taking part. He has vowed not to be so forgiving this time. 
Two weeks ago, the president, who has long wanted to tighten his control over the state-owned oil company, announced the suspension of nearly 100 executives and managers whom he charged with supporting or taking part in the strike. 
The move effectively executed his goal, and each day that he is able to keep the oil company -- and this country -- limping along is another day that he confounds and weakens the strategy of his opponents. 
Similarly, in April, the president purged senior officers from the ranks of the military. Today, that institution is more firmly in his command, and the armed forces have remained loyal to him throughout the current crisis. 
Time, analysts said, has shifted in the president's favor. The opposition, which once called for new elections, has turned its energy toward organizing a nonbinding referendum on Mr. Chavez's presidency for Feb. 2. The Supreme Court has yet even to rule on the legality of such a vote. In any case, no matter the outcome, the president says he intends to stay in power. 
But the price to Venezuela's economy, analysts agree, is hardly sustainable.
Mr. Chavez may succeed in securing his hold on the oil company, but for now, it is not one producing much oil. Last month, exports from the company, the world's fifth largest and a chief supplier to the United States, plummeted from more than 2.5 million barrels a day to less than 2 million barrels -- all month.
Ramon Espinasa, a former executive of the state-owned oil company and a consultant at the Inter-American Development Bank, said that without fully restoring oil production, Venezuela's gross domestic product would probably decline as much as 10 percent in the coming year. 
The government has already begun to dip into reserves, and will probably be forced to print more money next year, a move that could send inflation soaring past its already dizzying rate of 30 percent. Other analysts predicted a rash of bankruptcies, unemployment and migration that could shake the economy for months ahead. 
In addition to the economic turmoil, weeks of high-charged rhetoric between Mr. Chavez and his opponents have left the nation's nerves raw. The social divisions that have long marked life in this country have become as treacherous as minefields. 
On one side, Mr. Chavez, a former paratrooper who considers himself a champion of the poor, has refused to make concessions in negotiations with his opponents, calling their leaders "terrorists" and "coup plotters." Meanwhile, calls for violence, once an undercurrent of the crisis, now come openly in the opposition-controlled media and opposition rallies.
"Wasting our energy with marches no longer leads anywhere," wrote Armando Duran, a columnist for El Nacional, referring to almost daily protests by government opponents that draw hundreds of thousands of people. 
Mr. Duran added that the only way for the opposition not to be squashed by the government was for it to take its protests to the presidential compound at Miraflores, the site of violent clashes in April.
"We must confront him once and for all," Mr. Duran wrote, "and at whatever price." 
The top leader of Venezuela's strike on Thursday urged members of the armed forces to join the opposition against Mr. Chavez.
"What are you waiting for to accompany us?" asked one unionist, Carlos Ortega. "We understand the obedience you owe to the president of the republic, but obedience is one thing, being submissive is another."
Still, even as Venezuela faces a grim prospects for 2003, Mr. Chavez beams with strength. He boasts that neighboring countries have rallied to his aid, sending shipments of food and gasoline that have helped the government meet nation's most pressing needs. He said he would seek foreign oil experts to restart wells and refineries. He has pledged to normalize the oil industry within the month.
Most people believe that Mr. Chavez's optimism is overstated. Petroleos de Venezuela has some of the most sophisticated refining installations in the world, striking executives said. They need to run in order to keep functioning properly; the longer they are down, they longer it will take to get them up again.
Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, said the opposition's strategy might backfire. 
"The opposition was counting on people getting tired of President Chavez," he said. "But the opposition caused this crisis, and Chavez has every right to try to go out and fix it."
