HEADLINE: Today's Visions of the Science of Tomorrow 

 BODY:
At the end of every year, John Brockman, a literary agent and the publisher of Edge.org, a Web site devoted to science, poses a question to leading scientists, writers and futurists. In 2002, he asked respondents to imagine that they had been nominated as White House science adviser and that President Bush had sought their answer to "What are the pressing scientific issues for the nation and the world, and what is your advice on how I can begin to deal with them?" Here are excerpts of some of the responses. 

Mapping the Planet
 Over the last decade, the human genome project has laid the foundation for a comprehensive understanding of human biology. The translation of the new understanding into cures for human diseases will be a slow and difficult process. 
 Meanwhile, a new century has begun. It is time to begin a bold new initiative in biology: a planetary genome sequencing project to identify all the segments of the genomes of all the millions of species that live together on the planet.
This would require, first, the aggressive development of new technology for deciphering genes, comparable to the development of computer technology during the last half century, so that the cost of sequencing genes can continue to fall as rapidly as the cost of computing. 
The goal would be to complete the sequencing of the biosphere within less than half a century, at a cost comparable with the cost of the human genome. This project would bring an enormous increase in understanding of the ecology of the planet, which could then be translated into practical measures to sustain and improve the environment while allowing continued rapid economic development. It could also lead to the stabilization of the atmosphere and the climate. Let this century be the century of cures for planetary as well as human diseases.
-- Freeman Dyson, retired professor of physics, Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J.

Professor PlayStation
While American schools are notoriously underserving their students, American children are rushing home from class to learn how to succeed in the alternative universes of video games. They spend dozens of hours every week exploring virtual worlds, each with its own set of rules. Barring a complete overhaul of our schools, makers of game systems like Nintendo and PlayStation will continue to be the most successful institutions when it comes to captivating young minds.
South Korea has already figured this out. More than 60 percent of Korean homes have broadband Internet access -- and online, multiplayer role-playing games are immensely popular. Recently, the largest Korean textbook distributor and an independent software designer joined forces to make such a game in which children study math, science and history.
Here in the United States, the Army is using video games to reach teenagers. With a $7 million budget, it is building a series of games to be made available as a free download over the Web. The first title, "America's Army," helps players learn about war tactics by requiring them to rush through shooter missions armed with guns and grenades.
But where are the games created to teach young Americans civilian skills? While televisions and slide shows play a large role in classrooms, video games are still appallingly underused. Let's match the money and effort spent on "America's Army" to develop freely available games that teach about math and science, history and citizenship.
--Justin Hall, electronic entertainment journalist and creator of the Web site Justin's Links. 

Little Geniuses
We need more support for the most productive, and most underfinanced, scientific community in the country. These scientists and educators do more to provide the basic intellectual infrastructure of the nation than any other group. Every year they make fundamental discoveries in physics, biology, mathematics and psychology, as well as ensure that the discoveries of previous generations of scientists are passed on to future generations. Yet they typically receive salaries of zero to $15,000 a year, and 16 percent are below the poverty line. Most of the science educators in this group actually make major financial sacrifices to do their work. They receive less federal and state support than any other part of the scientific community -- no grants, no scholarships, no research and development write-offs. 
These unsung geniuses, are, of course, children under five and the many women (and a few men) who take care of them. This may seem like a motherhood issue; well, actually, it is a motherhood issue. But it's sound science policy too. Give our children what all scientists need --lunch, the right toys, a safe place to play, interesting problems to solve and someone to talk to, and watch them invent a new world.
-- Alison Gopnik, author of "The Scientist in the Crib: What Early Learning Tells Us About the Mind."

Think Small
The United States has been increasing its research efforts in a broad field called nanotechnology. Nanotechnology -- its name comes from the Greek work for dwarf -- refers to mechanical engineering on a molecular scale. Technology based on molecular manufacturing will lead to computer systems a billion times more powerful than what we have today, aerospace vehicles with 98 percent less structural mass, and medical tools that can repair tissues, organs and cells at a microscopic level. 
Molecular manufacturing will be based on molecular machine systems able to manipulate and assemble molecular components to make larger products. If you look in a conventional factory today, you will see electronic devices sensing and controlling processes, but the actual work shaping, moving and assembling parts is done by machines that, quite naturally, use moving parts to move parts.
Yet today's research programs are not focused on developing the molecular machine technologies essential to molecular manufacturing. Researchers often see any machinery as somehow archaic, left over from the 19th century. Thus interest in topics like biotechnology and microelectronics has diverted resources into short-term efforts that are worth doing, but not at the expense of neglecting the long-term promise of nanotechnology. 
--K. Eric Drexler, founder of the Foresight Institute and author of "Nanosystems: Molecular Machinery, Manufacturing and Computation; Unbounding the Future."

Science Without Secrets
My advice is to keep science public. Secret knowledge, no matter how laboriously acquired, is less than science.
Some knowledge, of course, must remain secret for the security of the nation. But unless there is a clear security risk, publish all else. Why? Science belongs to the people: they pay for it; they benefit from it. The benefits of scientific knowledge accrue far more rapidly when that knowledge lies open for all to see, to test and to try.
In my field, quantum computation, openness is beneficial. Quantum mechanics is famously weird, and one of the consequences of quantum weirdness is that even a small quantum computer, consisting of a few thousand atoms, has the potential to break all existing public-key cryptosystems.
As a result, quantum computers pose a significant threat to the security not only of classified encoded material, but also of most commercial transactions. Yet our national security agencies have elected to award grant money for quantum computing research with the stipulation that the results be published.
This is a wise policy. There is no doubt large-scale quantum computers will pose a risk to security. But they don't how exist, and constructing them will require the scientific and engineering community to solve wide-ranging problems of nanofabrication and control. The potential benefits of such research are a thousand times greater than any drawback from potential disruption to security.
-- Seth Lloyd, a professor of quantum-mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Fending Off the Big One
As an astrophysicist, I admit that few issues in my trade could be considered pressing. However, there is one aspect of my work that could have deadly consequences -- or, more precisely, will have deadly consequences if it is ignored. Here is where heaven and Earth meet: in the long-run certainty that people will die from the effects of an asteroid, large or small, hitting the planet.
NASA has been discovering and tracking asteroids, but the financing had not been sufficient to catalog most of them, and no money had gone to study how an asteroid might be deflected, even though the technology has, in principle, been available.
Fortunately, it is rather straightforward to develop a spacecraft that could reach a 100-meter diameter asteroid and give it a nudge so that it would miss the earth. For example, scientists have made great strides with plasma engines -- which are much more effective than traditional chemical engines and use radio waves to heat their fuel and magnetic fields to direct a stream of ultrahot ionized gases -- which could be used as space "tug boats."
All we have to do is carry out a test mission in which we demonstrate the ability to significantly alter an asteroid's orbit. Then when we discover an asteroid with our name on it, we will be prepared. Plasma engine advances would also speed up human expansion into space. This initiative could open the door to populating other worlds while at the same time making our own world a safer place.
-- Piet Hut, astrophysicist, Institute of Advanced Study, Princeton, N.J.

Intellectual Globalization
Both art and science address the most profound issues of the day yet often face each other across a great divide. A new National Institute for Humanism would encourage collaborations across the arts, humanities and sciences in tackling important questions about who and what we are. Call it the intellectual equivalent of globalization. 
Milan Kundera once wrote that every novel offers some answer to the question. "What is human existence and wherein does its poetry lie?" I submit that so does every work of important science.
-- Nancy Etcoff, author and instructor in the department of psychiatry at the Harvard Medical School.

Cassandras of the Labs
Scientists are as much victims of fashion as ordinary mortals are -- a fact illustrated by the rich history of junk science and false alarms of the last 30 years. Recall a few instances:
In the mid-1970's, many climatologists warned of an ice age that would severely diminish agricultural productivity by the year 2000.
In 1972, the United States banned DDT, only to find out, years later, that the evidence of the pesticide's harmful effects on human beings is inconclusive. In the meantime, millions of people -- 1 in 20 African children, for example -- have died of malaria, as Europe and the United States remain reluctant to support controlling mosquitoes with DDT.
And let's not forget the dire warnings about natural resources. In the 1970's, we were told that there would be essentially no oil left by the 1990's.
Science retains its alarmist streak today. The scuttlebutt among the scientists I know is that they have a better chance of getting a government or private grant if they indicate that their research might uncover a serious threat or problem. Media fascination with bad news is partly to blame, along with the principled gloominess and nagging of nongovernmental pressure groups. But government itself has played its natural part.
The point is not to be cynical about science fads but to know enough to choose wisely when it comes to supporting pure science, along with research that can give us beneficial technologies.
-- Denis Dutton, Department of Philosophy, University of Canterbury, New Zealand.

Really Popular Science
I believe that if 1 percent of the money now being distributed for science went to research that was of real interest to taxpayers, science would become more popular. 
At present, money generally goes to research sought by the scientific establishment, corporations and government bureaucracies. The administration of science is neither democratically accountable, nor carried out in a democratic spirit. 
My proposal is that 99 percent of the research funds continue to be allocated in the usual way. But I suggest that 1 percent be spent in a way that reflects the curiosity of lay people, who pay for all publicly financed research through taxes. It would be necessary to create a separate body. One possible name would be the National Discovery Center. 
The center would be governed by a board representing a wide range of interests, including nongovernmental organizations, schools and voluntary associations. Individuals could send suggestions in over the Internet. Local and national organizations could lobby for projects. Potential subjects for research could be discussed in the news media. 
This new venture would make science more attractive to young people, stimulate interest in scientific thinking and hypothesis-testing, and help break down the depressing alienation many people feel from science.
-- Rupert Sheldrake, author of "Dogs That Know When Their Owners Are Coming Home, and Other Unexplained Powers of Animals." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Ultimate Backup In the Backwoods; 
Using Remote Sites for Emergencies

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: STERLING FOREST, N.Y. 

 BODY:
Angelo Kosmidis isn't sure what a big-name computer company like I.B.M. does in the two nondescript office buildings at the entrance to this state park in Orange County, but he knows what the people working there like for breakfast: pancakes.
 What Mr. Kosmidis probably does not know is that each time he delivers the pancakes, he is walking into a building with "people traps." Any intruder who made it to the second-floor reception area, with or without pancakes, would be caught in a high-tech snare. The two shatterproof glass doors would close, and the elevator would drop to the first floor, stranding the intruder. The receptionist would run behind a steel door and into the back room where top-secret security codes are kept. 
 It may sound like an Austin Powers movie, and yet people in this business like it that way. Disaster recovery sites like this one operate as high-tech lifeboats for other companies that need a safe haven for their employees, or for electronic records in fires, floods or terrorist attacks. 
Tucked away among miles of tree-covered slopes and pristine lakes 45 miles from Manhattan, the I.B.M. Business Continuity and Recovery Center is symbolic of the disaster recovery industry. Open since 1993, the Sterling Forest center was an afterthought for many people. It was referred to as "the bunker" by those quasi-paramilitary emergency planning teams that were once the object of ridicule in some offices.
On Sept. 11, 2001, all of that changed. The unthinkable became real, and the bunker was a joke no more.
Among the assumptions that were challenged was the location of companies' existing recovery sites. Ken Brady, senior director at Krolls Crisis Management Group, a consulting firm, said one company had its offices in 1 World Trade Center and its backup site in 2 World Trade Center. "Everyone had thought if there's a fire in 1, we'd walk over to 2.' 
Another change: disaster recovery planners are no longer way down the food chain in corporate America, said Joseph Flach, vice president of Eagle Rock Alliance, a business continuity consulting firm. "Now we're selling to C.E.O.'s," he said.
Until Sept. 11, most companies focused almost exclusively on what they would do if they lost electronic files. They did not think the building itself would be gone, according to Jim Simmons, chief executive at Sungard Availability Services. Sungard, in Wayne, Pa., runs six large recovery centers, and along with I.B.M. dominates the field of disaster recovery services.
Information without people is useless, Mr. Simmons said, and companies now understand that. They have set up toll-free numbers so employees can call for directions on where to go, and are thinking about relocating the work itself. 
All of this comes in handy when planning for transit strikes as well as terrorist attacks. During the New York City transit union negotiations recently, several companies called I.B.M.'s Sterling Forest center to make sure they could put their emergency plans into action if employees could not get around the city.
Industry experts say it is hard to estimate how many recovery sites exist. Most are in "major N.F.L. cities," Mr. Simmons said. That is where large businesses are. The trick is being close enough to the original office but far enough away to escape the same threat, be it a hurricane or a terrorist. Thus Sterling Forest's 45 miles from Manhattan.
Here, companies can pay anywhere from a few hundred dollars a month for a computer and desks so employees can continue working in a disaster to hundreds of thousands of dollars to have entire computer systems replicated in buildings adjacent to the 17,863-acre state park. 
The I.B.M. center, whose lounge offers a striking view, might appear to be a resort if it were not for the security cameras at almost every door and the heavy, dark suitcases filled with tapes of data that arrive under top security.
And I.B.M., with its need for privacy, actually fits in alongside the few homes here, whose driveways bear signs warning hikers, "Private. Please Do Not Enter."
Those who enter find themselves in a brave new world. "We can run a report at every door your employee was at," said Christine Piazza, an executive administrator at the site.
No one, it turns out, can just walk through a door here. Doors require codes on security keypads. Each time a new code is about to be entered, the keypad first scrambles the numbers so that the top line rarely reads 1-2-3; instead it might read 4-8-2. A bystander cannot simply memorize by position the numbers someone else entered on the pad.
For those who make it past the door, there is not much to see. On one recent visit, the scene featured just desk after desk with computers and keyboards and phones, and a few middle-aged men moving cassettes of data from one rack to another. Other middle-aged men sit at computers with green blinking text, beneath a strip of clocks telling the hour in four time zones, from New York to Seattle.
But the needs of the people from the 40-some companies who came here after Sept. 11 were not so high-tech, according to an I.B.M. marketing executive, Pat Corcoran.
"The No. 1 request of people when they came here was, 'I need to get on Internet and e-mail,' " he said. In some cases they also needed chiropractors. Stress levels were high, Ms. Piazza said, and some employees had their backs worked on in the lounge overlooking Blue Lake.
When people are not recovering from a disaster, they are here testing.
Either way, there is no telling who might show up. Ms. Piazza has seen people arrive with pets (she found a kennel nearby). There are also sofas for sleeping overnight (pillows and blankets included) and showers in the bathrooms.
Yet despite the new interest brought on by Sept. 11, the future might not be too bright for recovery sites like the one in Sterling Forest. More companies are building their own backup sites, Mr. Brady said. They may work in New York City, for instance, but have office space and data backup on Long Island. Others disperse workers, leaving 300 workers in Manhattan and taking the other 300 to Westchester or New Jersey.
The slumping economy has also hurt the market, Mr. Brady said. Some travel companies have said they want to set up recovery plans, he said, but instead they are using their scarce money hoping just to keep hotels open.
In that sense, a disaster recovery plan is still not viewed as a must-have by some companies, according to Andy Hagg, executive editor of Contingency, Planning and Management magazine.
And even though Sept. 11 brought new focus to disaster recovery, terrorist attacks have not been and are unlikely to become the leading reason for disaster recovery. Every year, Mr. Hagg said, his magazine surveys companies for the causes of their disasters. It used to be that companies would cite natural disasters like hurricanes, he said. But in the last five years, companies have begun referring more and more frequently to "human error" and to computer problems like viruses.
But Mr. Simmons said sometimes computers do not have anything to do with the red alerts that disaster recovery sites get.
"You'd be surprised how many of those are water sprinklers going off," Mr. Simmons said.

At the super-secure recovery center, below, tucked away at a state park, steel doors and secret codes are de rigueur. (Photographs by James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL; 
Where The Tundra Is Always Frozen

BYLINE:  By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: GREEN BAY, Wis., Jan. 3 

 BODY:
It will not take the Atlanta Falcons long to realize the urgency of playoff football here on the frozen tundra. "Titletown" is painted on a hangar at the airport, Packers flags hang in the lobby and the gift shop offers all things cheese: cheese heads, cheese helmets, even cheese bras, all of which may appear as accessories at Saturday's first-round playoff game at Lambeau Field.
 "Ever see that guy at the games, St. Vincent?" asked Gary Stevens, a security official for the company that is remodeling Lambeau. "He wears a pope's hat with Vince Lombardi's picture on it. He's got a staff and the long robe in green and gold." 
 Janice Hylok has attended nearly every Packers home game since 1957, and will be at Saturday night's game, even if she has to miss a friend's anniversary party. During training camp each August, she puts up a holiday tree at home adorned with more than 100 green and gold ornaments. The tree stays up until after the Super Bowl. In the past, Hylok used a real tree, but it shed needles the way Paul Hornung once shed tacklers.
"Janice counts down the days to the Packers' preseason the way a lot of people count down the days to Christmas," a friend named Mark Hollister told The Green Bay Press-Gazette.
Even as the new sky-box reality is evident at renovated Lambeau Field, a small-town quaintness persists here alongside the wackiness, evoking a time when the economy of Ray Scott's voice -- "Starr . . . Dowler . . . touchdown" -- suggested that professional football was still more a game than a business. The Packers have won 12 National Football League titles, maintaining an intimacy and viability within a community of 102,000 whose fans serve as the team's stockholders.
The faithful are still stunned after the Packers lost, 42-17, last weekend to the Jets. "A high school team could have beaten them," Stacey Mosher said as he awaited lunch today at a sub shop. Home-field advantage throughout the National Football Conference playoffs has been lost to Philadelphia. Still, fans will pack Lambeau on Saturday night, assured in the knowledge that the Packers have never lost here in the postseason, and that the weather can be more blustery and chilling than a Lombardi tirade.
Winning isn't the only thing in January, snowing is. Saturday night's forecast calls for temperatures in the mid-20's with possible snow accumulation of one to three inches and a wind chill in the teens.
"Brett Favre weather," Stevens said in this morning's chill outside the stadium, his breath emerging white like steam from a smokestack. "It'll slow Vick down a little."
Packers fans know that Michael Vick, the Falcons' migratory quarterback, can run, but they wonder if he can skate. In the season opener here, Vick passed for 203 yards and a touchdown, and ran for 72 additional yards and another touchdown, as the Falcons extended the Packers into overtime before losing, 37-34.
That was September; this is January.
The Falcons are accustomed to playing in a dome, where the offense is as climate-controlled as orchids. This time of year, Green Bay more closely resembles "Holiday on Ice" in shoulder pads. The turf is more conducive to double axels than double reverses. If there is one visiting athlete who might be comfortable in these conditions, it is Brian Boitano.
"We're not playing in a dome down there or on a summer day up here," Green Bay Coach Mike Sherman said of Vick. "You'd think that maybe the turf wouldn't help him."
Vick said he played at Virginia Tech, where it snowed frequently. Dan Reeves, the Atlanta coach and aspiring meteorologist, said, "He's still going to be faster than most people, whatever track it is." 
Speaking of turf, it made front-page news today in the local paper. Lake Superior State University of Michigan has included "frozen tundra" on its 2003 List of Words Banished From the Queen's English for Misuse, Overuse and General Uselessness. On the 35th anniversary of the famed Ice Bowl, when Bart Starr sneaked into the end zone and Dallas defenders skidded along the goal line as if wearing blades instead of cleats, the term frozen tundra has been declared hopelessly redundant.
So what, the locals say. Jumbo shrimp is an awkward term and people still use it. The usage of frozen tundra is not likely to thaw any time soon, unlike the actual turf at Lambeau Field, which is kept from freezing by an underground heating system. 
According to the Packers, "frozen tundra" originated with N.F.L. Films and the voice-of-God portentousness of the announcer John Facenda. Chris Berman has imitated the phrase to great effect on ESPN in a tone that is both reverent and satirical. If the arbiters at Lake Superior State have declared that frozen tundra has jumped the shark, locals suggest, perhaps they have played in too many GE College Bowls without their helmets, or thinking caps.
Redundancy is not all bad, said Harvey Kaye, a history professor at the University of Wisconsin-Green Bay. "I always figure people learn better when they hear it twice," he said.
Brian Sutton, an English professor at the university, recalled a student at Vince Lombardi Middle School saying before a Monday night game against Miami last November, "Dolphins usually eat fish; tonight, they're eating frozen tundra."
"It's a redundancy worth keeping," Sutton said. "When I moved here from Chattanooga, my friends said, 'You're going to the frozen tundra.' It gives us an identity. Without the Packers, we're Skokie, Illinois."

HEADLINE: Crisis in Korea Stirs Debate In a Borough In New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: PALISADES PARK, N.J., Jan. 3 

 BODY:
They tape American flags to their front doors, sprinkle English words into their banter and turn emotional when speaking of their adopted homeland. But for many of the 36,000 Korean-Americans who have settled in and around this tidy, blue-collar borough, the growing crisis on the Korean peninsula is provoking anxiety, stirring passionate debate and straining allegiances as never before.
 Like their relatives and friends in South Korea, they worry about North Korea's nuclear aspirations, the prospect of war and the possibility that the current standoff, even if it remains a diplomatic one, will defer their dreams for a unified Korea. 
 "Every day there is no peace is another day that I will not get to see my mother," said Myung Sun Park, 68, a retired tailor who was separated from his family during the Korean War more than 50 years ago. "Seeing the news brings me so much heartache." 
But as they watch South Korea and the United States drift farther apart over policy toward the north, the accountants, greengrocers and beauticians who have prospered here are increasingly troubled by the anti-American tempest brewing in the streets of Seoul and by the words of the newly elected president, Roh Moo Hyun, who has questioned the White House's hard-nosed stance toward North Korea's authoritarian leader, Kim Jong Il.
Like many South Koreans who came of age during the cold war, Tim Lee, 45, thinks the demonstrations in Seoul, which have drawn thousands of youthful protesters, are misguided, even reckless. After all, he said, more than 54,000 Americans lost their lives defending the south, and since the war ended, 37,000 soldiers have been stationed there to discourage an invasion from the Communist north.
"I feel sad and ashamed," Mr. Lee said, sitting in the computer shop he owns on Broad Avenue, the bustling commercial spine of Palisades Park, where more than a third of the residents are Korean. "You sacrificed so much for us, and now you probably feel let down when they say, 'Yankee, go home.' "
Jee Jung, 30, a reporter at The Korean Times, a newspaper published in Queens, said many Korean-Americans were hypersensitive about the fraying relationship between Seoul and Washington, once among the world's most reliable alliances. With the news from Korea featuring daily protests and shop signs that say, "Americans Not Welcome Here," their fear, he said, is that they will be stigmatized here.
"The situation after Sept. 11, and the sentiment toward Muslims -- they don't want that to happen to them," said Mr. Jung, who does freelance reporting for The New York Times.
Jay Lee, 61, a real estate broker and American citizen who arrived here 30 years ago, said he feared the opposite: that he would no longer be welcome in the country of his birth, where much of his family still lives. "I hear it's dangerous now to carry an American passport over there or speak openly your pro-American opinions," he said, his voice hushed and his face etched with worry. "It can bring you personal danger, and that makes me sad."
Still, many of the two dozen people interviewed here acknowledged a measure of sympathy for the protesters, saying that their unhappiness over America's prolonged military presence and its tough words for North Korea could not be easily dismissed. They said that an armed conflict between the north and south would primarily affect Korean civilians.
"President Bush seems to think violence can solve any problem," said Helen Lee, 35, a pharmacist and a mother of two. "But if there is war, we will pay the price."
Such sentiments -- that the United States does not have Korea's best interests in mind -- are fueling much of the anger in South Korea. After decades of treating North Korea like a peril and a pariah, and using economic sanctions as a cudgel, South Korea now views dialogue and economic engagement as the best paths toward peace. South Koreans, not Americans, they say, should solve the problems in their own backyard. 
Long-simmering resentments boiled over last June after an American armored vehicle accidentally killed two Korean schoolgirls north of the capital. A United States military court later acquitted those involved in the incident, and a White House apology, read by the American ambassador, was widely viewed as insincere.
"America is very strong, so we wonder why President Bush would not himself apologize for what happened," said Yong Ja Lee, who was celebrating her 35th birthday with friends at the New Shin La Bakery. "That only makes America seem more arrogant and makes people angry."
The rift between the United States and South Korea widened further after President Bush made a speech last year grouping North Korea with Iraq and Iran in an "axis of evil." Two weeks ago, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld heightened tensions by warning the north that the United States could wage two wars at once. His statement was in response to North Korea's announcement that it would restart a nuclear reactor that had been closed under an agreement with the Clinton administration.
But like many others here, Jae Ko, 32, a jeweler, said the current face-off was not as dangerous as the news media had made it out to be. After all, he added, the two nations have been officially at war since the 1950's. 
"At this point, I don't think North Korea is that stupid to start up a war," he said. "But if there is one, it will be because of the U.S."

HEADLINE: G.M. Lifts Market Share On Sales Burst In December 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
General Motors, intent on increasing its market share for the second consecutive year, turned to a fire sale last month that lifted sales 36 percent and helped it accomplish its goal, according to figures released today.
 The back-to-back annual gain in market share was the first since 1976, but it was made possible by zero percent financing deals and reliance on less profitable sales to corporate and rental fleets. Now Wall Street and Detroit are wondering whether several years of outsize vehicle sales, propped up by increasingly large incentives from the Big Three, will make a feast or famine of 2003. Added to that is the uncertain economy and the potential for war in Iraq. 
 "I think the industry is on a terrible treadmill," said John Casesa, an analyst for Merrill Lynch, who expects industry sales to fall to 16.2 million cars and trucks this year from 16.8 million in 2002, which was the fourth-best year on record for United States sales. 
"They used big discounts in December, and now they have to deal with the aftermath in January," Mr. Casesa added.
G.M.'s share of the United States market, as high as 60 percent in the early 1960's, stands at 28.7 percent. For the industry, G.M.'s big month led to the best December on record and a 14.4 percent increase compared with the month a year earlier, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a company in Southfield, Mich., that tracks auto sales. 
For December, Ford posted a gain of 8.2 percent and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler reported a 1 percent increase, but it was G.M. that had the blowout month.
"G.M. had an excellent year in 2002 on all fronts," John Smith, group vice president for North American vehicle sales, said in a statement.
Mack McPherson, sales manager at Burt Chevrolet in Englewood, Colo., a suburb of Denver, said his dealership sold 246 new Chevy cars and trucks last month, compared with fewer than 200 in October and November. It was propelled by huge sales for the Suburban and Tahoe sport utility vehicles.
"They put zero percent on those two vehicles around the 18th or 20th, and they took off," he said. "People just went crazy."
"Getting all those commercials, and zero percent, and the cash back, that drives the market," he said. "As soon as people hear that, they say, 'Honey, it's time to go buy a car.' "
Suburbans, Tahoes and other light trucks -- a government classification that includes sport utility vehicles, trucks and minivans -- outsold passenger cars for the second consecutive year. 
In 1980, only about a fifth of sales came from light trucks. The growth of light trucks, particularly S.U.V.'s, has increased the gas consumption of the average automobile despite advances in technology and has led environmentalists into an increasingly adversarial relationship with Detroit over issues like emissions of greenhouse gases and smog-forming pollutants. 
It has also had considerable safety implications; light trucks have a higher death rate for their own occupants because of their tendency to roll over, and they pose increased dangers when they collide with passenger cars. 
But light trucks are Detroit's chief profit center at a time of only modest profitability and fierce competition from abroad. 
Of particular concern for analysts is the disparity in what the Big Three and foreign automakers spend on incentives. G.M. spent $2,431 a vehicle for the year through November, and that almost certainly rose in December. By comparison, Toyota spends $526 a vehicle on incentives, according to the Autodata Corporation. G.M. announced an extensive new round of incentive offers today, including many five-year, zero percent offers and financing as low as 1.9 percent on six-year deals. 
"Ultimately, this is just kind of more of the same," said Rod Lache, an analyst for Deutsche Bank. "The auto industry lowers prices and the market responds, but I don't think this is a good thing for automakers. These guys are going for volume instead of profitability, and that's not constructive for the industry."
Jim O'Connor, the head of the Ford division of Ford Motor, said: "Affordability has been very favorable for consumers, and I think it will continue to drive retail sales. Some people might be skittish about some uncertainties, perhaps in the Mideast, but you certainly can't prove it when you look at vehicle sales."
Ford also spent heavily on incentives last month, though Mr. O'Connor said the company spent about 25 percent less than G.M. Officials at Chrysler said they also decided not to match G.M.'s incentives.
"The industry went in to kind of an incentive spending spree during the month of December," said Gary E. Dilts, Chrysler's senior vice president for sales. "We elected not to participate at the highest level of that spending spree. That's bad news if you're counting the sales tickets in the month of December, it's good news if you're managing the profitability of the Chrysler Group."
Diane Swonk, an economist at Bank One, said the big month "shows what we knew all along, that the consumer that everyone thought couldn't hold it up was an Atlas and shouldered the burden of the economy." Ms. Swonk took advantage of the deals and traded in her Saturn for a CTS, the flashy, sharp-edged new sedan from Cadillac. She says she thinks sales will fall to about 15.8 million cars and trucks this year.
"There's got to be some givebacks, but that's what we all said last year," she added.
She says she does believe, though, that earnings can hold up because of productivity gains.
Mr. Casesa is less optimistic. He predicts G.M.'s earnings will fall to $3 a share this year from a projected $6.67 a share last year and that Ford's earnings will decline to 30 cents a share this year from an estimated 45 cents last year.
David Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities, said G.M. "did achieve their goal of two years in a row of higher market share; on the other hand I think they pulled in some of their January volume into December and as a result January sales could be kind of sick."
Paul Ballew, G.M.'s chief industry sales analyst, said, "We do believe there is a bit of payback as we've stressed previously though we don't want to overstate that."
Over all, sales in 2002 fell 2 percent from 2001, which was the second-best year, with 17.2 million vehicles sold. Several foreign automakers had their best years ever, including BMW, with sales up 20 percent; Honda, which posted a 3.3 percent rise; and Toyota, whose sales were up 1 percent. By comparison, G.M.'s sales fell about 1 percent, while Ford's dropped 8.8 percent and Chrysler's declined 3 percent.

HEADLINE: A Bored Shopper's Lament: Seen a Store,Seen Them All 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
America's stores are caught in an identity crisis. 
 Shoppers are bored, complaining that they cannot tell one pair of khakis or ribbed turtleneck or Fair Isle sweater from another. And even worse, they cannot tell one store from another. 
 Many pollsters and analysts blame the recent holiday retailing debacle -- one of the most disappointing seasons in at least 10 years -- on the inability of merchants to set themselves apart from their competition and generate enough excitement to make customers leave their houses and spend. 
"More than ever before, a store must attract a group of core customers," said Robert F. Buchanan, the chief retail analyst for A. G. Edwards. "They need loyal shoppers who will return, again and again, through higher prices and low, to keep the registers ringing." 
Once, shoppers say, stores had distinct personalities. Lord & Taylor's catered to Greenwich, Conn., matrons; Bloomingdale's to jet-setters; Eddie Bauer was big with the wood-smoke-and-golden-retrievers crowd; and the Gap specialized in putting baby boomers in khakis and T-shirts. 
"Now they say they don't know what they're going to find where," said Britt Beemer, chairman of America's Research Group, which tracks consumer preferences. "Seventy-four percent of consumers interviewed over the past two years -- more than a half-million of them -- say all stores look alike within their category." 
Marvin Traub, the former chairman of Bloomingdale's, blames the sameness at stores, particularly department stores, on "pressure on the bottom line." The desperation to show profits "pushed the stores into a less innovative dependence on the same suppliers," Mr. Traub said. "This took the edge off the creativity and excitement of fashion." 
A look at efforts by five big chains -- Lord & Taylor, the Limited, Kohl's, Target and Neiman Marcus -- to hang onto core customers in a weak shopping environment underscores how crucial a clear identify is turning out to be.

Lord & Taylor
Lord & Taylor was once the symbol of what analysts call "the carriage trade" -- middle-aged and older matrons, wearing fitted tweed suits with patent leather pumps. But the store lost its way more than a decade ago by trying to captivate the teenage crowd with noisy displays. 
Now, under Jane Elfers, a relatively new, down-to-earth chief executive, Lord & Taylor is trying to recapture old customers while pulling in some new shoppers aged 30 to 44.
"When I arrived in June 2000, I determined to bring back Lord & Taylor's specialty store roots," Ms. Elfers said this week. "During the 1990's, it had become a department store; it had lost its cachet and was selling a lot of the same brands as at the malls. We were trying to compete on price, and it wasn't a winning strategy for us."
The new team waded in, refining the merchandise and cleaning up the clutter in all 86 stores. Analysts say the team has moved accessories to the front doors, to broaden the merchandise, "to show they're not just about frumpy dresses and Grandma's clothes," said Marshal Cohen, research director of NPD Fashionworld, a market survey company.
Ms. Elfers set up the first internal design team, and directed the manufacture of a handful of private label styles, with younger-sounding names: Kate Hill, Metropolitan and -- guess what -- Identity. 
The store has also stopped trying to capture teenagers: "That's really not our DNA," she said. The core customer, Ms. Elfers says, "is jealously guarded," with more traditional skirts and dresses. She said she was looking forward to 2003, which has already been christened "the year of the dress." 
Analysts are less sanguine about Lord & Taylor's prospects. Although the stores look elegant with their pink marble floors and crystal table lamps on the counters, Lord & Taylor is still perceived as a troubled moderate-price department store. 
"They're still alienating their core customers," Mr. Buchanan of A. G. Edwards said. "When I walk into one of their stores, I still don't see the jacket women want to wear to work. Where are the clothes for the woman who is 5 foot 4 and 140 pounds?" While he said the store's sales figures were improving, Lord & Taylor is "still significantly negative," the analyst said.
At May Department Stores, which owns Lord & Taylor, same-store sales declined 5.8 percent in November (the company does not break out separate figures for its 11 store chains). Elaine Francolino, a vice president and senior credit officer at Moody's Investors' Service, said Moody's credit rating for May was high, but the outlook was negative. "We believe their margin and operating may not return to levels of the past because of increased competition," she said, citing Kohl's and other moderate-price stores.

The Limited
Things have been rocky at the Limited, and its sister, the Express chain, for some time, largely because of the classic identity problem: the store lost its fashion sense by worrying about the bottom line -- and going to a more generic look.
"Their iconic items like the Firenze sweaters have disappeared from their assortments -- they don't have a single key item," said Richard Jaffe, a retail analyst with UBS Warburg. "They were known for a single look for each season." 
On the day before New Year's, customers standing in line at a Limited store in the King of Prussia, Pa., mall agreed that something had gone wrong a couple of years ago -- but they said that the store was finding itself again.
"They went down because they became too businesslike," said Rini Sen, 22, a student at the University of Maryland. Now, Ms. Sen says, the Limited is coming back to recognizing what its core shoppers want: lighthearted, dressy separates. 
"See this top?" she said, holding up a black stretch one-shoulder top with a ruffle. "This is what I'm buying." 
The analysts agree that the Limited may be discovering its fashion recipe. "They are succeeding in defining a target customer and appealing to her," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Jaffee said the Limited has "improved its offerings significantly in the last year, to include more unique fashions." 
Nevertheless, on Friday, Lazard lowered its December same-store estimate from plus 2 to negative one-half for Limited Brands, which owns the Limited and Express. In offering this assessment, Todd Slater, an analyst, wrote that gift card sales -- which register when the cards are cashed in, not when they are purchased -- may lift sales in January and February. Mr. Buchanan of A. G. Edwards predicted that Limited's earnings would rise in the spring, because of its more pulled-together fashions.

Kohl's
Since Kohl's went public a decade ago, expanding from 76 stores to 457, shoppers have warmed to its seemingly ideal formula, which combined a specialty store environment -- wooden shelves and attractive wall dividers -- with a down-and-direct price-cutting strategy. Customers say they love the $30 Nikes, and the two-for-$9 (on sale) cotton towels. By having lots of stock on a few models in each brand, the store satisfied picky bargain-hunting customers used to stores like T.J. Maxx, which have good brands and great prices but maybe only one pair of Levi's -- in size 3.
But to a few analysts, Kohl's strategy now may not be quite so perfect. Several wonder if it will lose its niche as it is squeezed above and below. The rapidly expanding chain is being nibbled on the bottom by Wal-Mart and Target, chains featuring much better apparel than discount stores ever had before -- and down from the top by traditional department stores like Lord & Taylor and Nordstrom, which are marking goods down even below Kohl's prices. In November, Kohl's same-store sales were down 3.4 percent from the year earlier. 
A spokeswoman said that Kohl's had carefully defined its core customer, and was sticking to its goal of high quality at moderate prices.
Larry Montgomery, the chain's chief executive, has announced that the company will continue to expand: in the coming year, it plans to open 80 stores, including 40 in the Southwest; its first store in Southern California is to open in the spring and be followed by an entry into Las Vegas in the fall. 
Ms. Francolino of Moody's remains optimistic. "Based on what customers want, Kohl's has been very successful," she said. "Maybe they had one or two months where same-store sales declined, but Kohl's has a business model that we believe will continue to be successful."

Target
For several years, Target had the hippest advertising campaign in the industry, which, month after month, drove customers into its stores. But now, while the company has kept the campaign, some analysts say that the stores do not really look all that different from Kmarts. 
A recent visit to the Target in Queens confirmed what analysts have been saying for the last few months: both the store layout and its employees seemed confused. It was impossible to find the Michael Graves whistling tea kettles that Target made famous, although there was a display of other, cheaper models.
Disgruntled shoppers say they have not been able to find a lot of the more chic advertised offerings -- including the new Philippe Starck take on Tupperware.
Target did not comment on its recent performance. But the chain, analysts say, risks alienating some of its core customers -- the would-be fashionistas who want to grab a stylish look for a cheap price -- unless it makes the company look as chic as the ads.
While they praise Target's increasingly fashionable clothes by Mossimo and Merona, some analysts worry about Target's recent entry into the food business. "Their strategy is questionable," Mr. Buchanan said. 
Mr. Slater still champions Target for its upscale merchandise assortment, including a separate Sony line of consumer electronics -- CD players and DVD machines -- made just for Target. The children's furniture competes with Pottery Barn, he said, for a lot less money. 
"Naturally, the apparel doesn't compete with Bergdorf Goodman," he said. "After all, it's a discounter."

Neiman Marcus
Many analysts say that these stores have done the best job of keeping core customers. Unlike many other stores, which fell over backward trying to be hip or cheap, or both, Neiman kept its luxury shopper. Even so, the economy is bound to affect the stores. After all, with stockbroker bonuses down and the bankers running for cover, won't the number of women who can afford a $595 pair of Manolo Blahnik shoes be cut down?
Perhaps not. Neiman Marcus's same-store sales for November were up 5.8 percent -- a rarity in an ocean of negative numbers -- and executives boasted that their stores had fewer marked-down goods than other stores. According to Ms. Francolino of Moody's, Neiman has "targeted the right customer niche." Yet Neiman's credit rating is lower than both Target and Kohl's -- largely because its success is limited to 32 stores. 
"Neiman's is not a large operation," Ms. Francolinosaid. "They can't roll out 100 stores, because the store must keep its cachet. Its potential for growth is a lot more limited than some, because of those upscale shoppers." She paused. "They've got a terrific customer base."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ASIAN ARENA; 
New Seoul Leader to Press U.S. and North to Yield a Bit

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE with ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: SEOUL, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, a former labor negotiator, is preparing a compromise proposal that would require both North Korea and the United States to accept concessions to resolve the standoff over the Communist state's nuclear program, an aide said today.
 Mr. Roh hopes to resolve the dispute before he takes office Feb. 25, Lim Chae Jung, head of the presidential transition team, said on SBS-TV, one of the main television channels. The Yonhap news agency reported that one proposal under study would require North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program in exchange for a written guarantee of security from the United States. 
 In Beijing today, North Korea's Ambassador to China, Choe Jin Su, called on Washington to reopen talks. "The U.S. should respect the international community and respond to dialogue without any preconditions," Mr. Choe told reporters today, adding that his country was "compelled" to restart its nuclear program and to expel inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency. He said Pyongyang would resume negotiations on the nuclear issue if Washington would guarantee North Korea's security. 
In response to the ambassador's remarks, the Bush administration repeated today its precondition for talks: that North Korea stop its two programs to build nuclear bombs.
"The issue is not nonaggression," the State Department's spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, said in Washington today. "The issue is whether North Korea will verifiably dismantle this nuclear enrichment program."
"We have no intention to sit down and bargain again, to pay for this horse again," Mr. Boucher said, referring to North Korea's decision last month to walk away from a 1994 agreement that provided North Korea with two light-water reactors and a supply of free fuel oil in exchange for closing a reactor that could produce weapons-grade plutonium. "We are not entering into a negotiation," he said, "in order to get them to commit to something that they've already committed to." 
In a similar news conference in Moscow this week, North Korea's ambassador to Russia suggested that North Korea would withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
"The North Koreans have used their ambassadors to float trial balloons in the past," said Scott Snyder, Korea representative of The Asia Foundation, a research group partly financed by the United States government. He cited a similar pattern of news conferences held to stage-manage the crisis over North Korea's nuclear program in 1993-94. 
Referring to the North's latest offer, he added: "It's a non-starter. Now that there is a clear condition for dialogue, it is easy to call for unconditional dialogue."
But offering clues to the new policy of South Korea's future president, a top aide to Mr. Roh said tonight that dialogue was the only way out of Korea's nuclear standoff. 
"The new government calls for dialogue, and President Bush just mentioned two days ago that North Korea's program could be resolved through diplomacy," Ben Q. Limb, press adviser to the president- elect, said in respnse to the news that the North Korean ambassador had called for dialogue. "Now, can there be diplomacy without dialogue?" 
In fact, North Korea's nuclear brinkmanship is provoking intense rounds of discussion, but not of the kind that it is expected to like.
Today, John R. Bolton, under secretary of state for arms control and international security, left on a weeklong trip to Asia. On Monday and Tuesday, the United States, South Korea and Japan will coordinate strategy in Washington. With a common policy in hand, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs, James A. Kelly, then plans to tour capitals in the region.
Separately, a South Korean envoy, the vice foreign minister, Kim Han Kyung, met with Chinese officials on Thursday, and flew from Beijing to Moscow today.
With an eye to this intense diplomatic activity, North Korea's ambassador to Beijing said other countries should urge Washington to talk with North Korea to conclude a nonaggression treaty.
"If other countries are concerned about nuclear security on the Korean Peninsula, they should urge the United States to assure us of security, and if they can't do that, they should be quiet," he said. "The Bush administration has been saying the whole time it has no intention of invading our country. We can't believe that. Who can believe these words?"
For his part, President Bush had some strong words this week for Kim Jong Il, North Korea's leader. Mr. Bush said he had "no heart for somebody who starves his folks." 
North Korea, long isolated internationally, is now more isolated than ever. Russia and China, its historic allies, now have thriving and profitable ties with the booming economy of the South.
Eyeing the possibility that huge amounts of South Korean freight traffic could travel along the Trans-Siberian Railroad, Russia has devoted much diplomatic energy to encouraging North Korea to allow trains to cross the Demilitarized Zone separating the North from the South. After months of land-mine removal and construction work, test trains are expected to cross the heavily fortified border this month.
China, which keeps friendly relations with both Seoul and Pyongyang, sends aid to the North while strengthening trade and investment ties with South Korea. 
Meanwhile, North Korea's brief fall honeymoon with Japan now seems long over. Today, Pyongyang concentrated its fire on Japan, the nation in the region that has proved to be most sympathetic to Washington's hard line on the nuclear program. Calling Japan's stance a "suicidal act," said the official daily, Rodong Sinmum. "It is like poking one's eyes with one's own hands."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Choe Jin Su, North Korea's ambassador to China, said in Beijing yesterday that Washington should reopen talks with his country. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Surgeons Explain Reasons for Their Walkout 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WEIRTON, W. Va., Jan. 3 

 BODY:
An ambulance with lights flashing and siren screaming wheeled into the Weirton Medical Center here on Thursday afternoon, carrying a 30-year-old steelworker writhing in pain.
 Dr. Mitch Fuscardo, director of the emergency room, quickly determined that the man had a kidney stone blockage and that a surgeon was needed to remove the stone. 
 But there was no one to do the work. Half the hospital's 20 full-time surgeons had taken themselves off the duty roster at midnight on New Year's Eve to protest the high cost of medical malpractice insurance in West Virginia. Technically, they have taken leaves of absence. 
Surgeons at three hospitals in Wheeling, about 25 miles to the south, also stopped routine work. Today, doctors here said that colleagues in two or three other towns might soon join in.
So far only surgeons are involved. Their work is regarded as among the riskiest in medicine, and they pay the highest insurance premiums, as much as $150,000 a year. 
"I'm doing this because I want to stay in West Virginia," Dr. Charles P. Capito said. "It's gotten to the point where you can't afford malpractice insurance in this state. We've been begging the Legislature to do something for years."
Dr. Capito said his insurance bill this year was $54,000, up from $42,000 last year and $30,000 the year before.
"I feel tremendous support for the physicians who have walked out," said Dr. Joe Endrich, an internist and the chairman of the board of the Weirton Medical Center. "But I can't call my practice elective. I'd consider myself abandoning my patients if I was not available to them."
The protest, which the surgeons are unwilling to call a strike, is only the latest sign of a backlash around the country against the rising cost of malpractice insurance. 
The problem has been building for several years and has been most severe in West Virginia, Florida, Mississippi, Nevada, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Both as a result of increasingly large jury awards and settlements and because of bad business decisions and the slump in the stock markets, medical malpractice insurers have been unable to turn a profit. 
Several companies have collapsed and several have stopped selling this type of insurance. Companies still in the business have been sharply raising prices and offering coverage only to the doctors they think are least likely to be sued. As a result, some doctors have seen their premiums double or triple; some have been able to buy coverage only through special state programs.
In some states doctors are retiring early or avoiding risky procedures to lower their premiums. In the last year, more than 100 West Virginia doctors have moved to other states where insurance rates are considered more tolerable.
Doctors in this old steel town in the hilly sliver of West Virginia that is wedged between Pennsylvania and Ohio said they would jump in were they needed to save a life. But for other situations that may be merely painful, like the steelworker's kidney stones, or inconvenient, like a delay of a hernia operation, they are keeping hands off.
People in this hardscrabble region can sympathize. But even strong union members like Robert Eltringham, a retired sheet metal worker, have been taken aback that such a drastic step was taken.
"It's a little disheartening that they would walk out like this," Mr. Eltringham said. "People depend on the doctors."
Yet Erma Rangos, who owns a women's clothing store, said, "They need to do something," adding, "Maybe it will benefit us all."
When Dr. Fuscardo tried to help the steelworker in the emergency room, all he could do was order some tests, administer pain medicine and try to find a surgeon in Pennsylvania or Ohio who would take the case. He ended up sending the patient to the Trinity Medical Center West in Steubenville, Ohio, a 15-minute ambulance trip across the Ohio River.
Other doctors transferred another man with a kidney stone blockage to Trinity West on New Year's Day. The same day, a 91-year-old woman who broke an arm in a fall was also sent there.
There have been no life-threatening situations yet, but Dr. Endrich said that in just three days there had been "tremendous disruption" for patients. He said that the dozen or so family doctors and internists in Weirton, a blue-collar town of about 25,000 people, regularly send patients for surgical evaluations to the medical center. But now, he said, patients were being sent to hospitals in Pittsburgh, about 40 miles to the east. "I've sent at least 20 patients to Pittsburgh myself in these last few days," he said.
As the number of medical malpractice lawsuits has risen in the state, several insurers have left West Virginia, saying they cannot make a profit even with increased premiums. In 2001, Gov. Bob Wise pushed through a program in which the state provides coverage to many doctors. But premiums remain high.
The doctors want a reduction in their overall insurance costs; a ceiling of $250,000 imposed on claims of pain and suffering; and help in getting higher payments for their work from health insurers. 
The doctors here said they watched colleagues in Nevada and Mississippi get the attention of state officials by staging protests. They said that after talking with aides to Governor Wise for weeks, they decided they should take a stand, too. 
"The physicians have been screaming for years about the malpractice problem and they feel it has been falling on deaf ears," said Don Muhlenthaler, the chief executive of the medical center. 
The doctors here were encouraged by the success of colleagues in Pennsylvania who threatened to stop working on New Year's Day. In Pennsylvania, Ed Rendell, the incoming governor, got the doctors to stay on the job by vowing to urge the legislature to cut insurance costs for surgeons in the riskiest fields significantly and to push for new procedures to reduce frivolous lawsuits against doctors and hospitals.
So far in West Virginia, Governor Wise has been unable to mollify the doctors. At a meeting with three surgeons from Wheeling Thursday evening at the State House in Charleston, Governor Wise spoke of "sweeping plans" for limitations on lawsuits and "also promised to address our economic problems," said one of the surgeons, Dr. Gregory Saracco.
But Dr. Saracco, a general surgeon, said that the governor refused to provide any details, saying he would do so in his annual address to the state legislature on Wednesday.
Dr. Saracco said Mr. Wise urged him and his colleagues to abandon their protest. "I tend to feel I should be able to trust the governor," Dr. Saracco said. But he said he had not decided whether to resume work. 
Here in Weirton, Dr. Capito, an orthopedic surgeon, said he would continue protesting at least until the governor's address. "We'll see what he says then," Dr. Capito said.

UAL Layoffs Reach Managers
United Airlines plans to lay off 14 percent of its management and salaried work force, about 1,500 employees, by Jan. 19. The airline will also close its remaining 32 ticket offices in cities by Jan. 28. C2

Strong December for G.M.
General Motors posted strong sales in December and gained market share in 2002 for the second consecutive year, but the automaker's heavy reliance on consumer incentives could lead to a lean 2003. C1

Identity Crisis for Retailers
Many analysts blame the recent holiday retailing debacle on the inability of merchants to set themselves apart from their competition and keep loyal customers coming back. C1

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Exports Grow In Several Nations 

BYLINE:  By Wayne Arnold (NYT)

 BODY:
 Demand for electronics from within Asia appears to be keeping the region's export engines turning even as the crucial United States market slows. 
Malaysia and the Philippines both reported strong export growth for November, thanks largely to higher electronics shipments to Japan, China and elsewhere in Asia. Compared with the month before, Malaysian exports in November slowed, but they were still up about 10 percent, but in the Philippines, export growth accelerated to 18 percent. Exports to the United States , however, showed a decline in both countries. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
POLYMEDICA WORKERS TOLD TO EXPECT F.B.I. QUERIES

BYLINE:  Reuters

 BODY:
 Employees of the PolyMedica Corporation were warned by its chief executive yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation will begin questioning them in a fraud investigation. PolyMedica, a medical products maker in Woburn, Mass., is a target of criminal and civil inquiries by federal agencies and the United States attorney's office for the Southern District of Florida. 
The investigation, which is nearly two years old, is focusing on suspected abuses that include health care fraud within the government's Medicare program. In a memo to employees posted on PolyMedica's Web site, the chief executive, Samuel Shanaman, said, "If you are contacted, it is our strong desire that you fully cooperate with federal investigators." The company's stock fell $3.46, to $27.62 a share.

HEADLINE: United to Lay Off 1,500 More Employees 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG

 BODY:
United Airlines said yesterday that it would lay off nearly 1,500 management and salaried employees by Jan. 19.
 That is a 14 percent reduction in its management and salaried work force, and a 1.9 percent decline from its total work force of 80,000. 
 United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, has been struggling to restructure its business since filing for bankruptcy protection on Dec. 9. It has to meet certain monthly cash flow expectations set forth by its four lenders so that it can obtain access to $700 million of loans. United said yesterday that the layoffs would help it achieve the cost cuts needed to reach those cash flow goals. 
The airline also said it would close its remaining 32 city ticket offices by Jan. 28, resulting in the layoffs of 188 more workers.
Dan Walsh, United's vice president for sales, said in a statement that United customers were increasingly buying tickets online or through a reservations hot line. This made the city ticket offices unnecessary, he said.
United has not decided who among its management and salaried employees will be laid off. It said it would send notices to the affected workers as soon as those decisions were made.
"These changes are part of the process of creating a new business that is competitive, customer-focused and sustainable," Sara Fields, United's senior vice president in charge of people, said in a statement.
Last week, United put a message on its employee hot line saying that "significant layoffs are likely in the short run." The company said that it had recorded that message because a federal law required it to give advance warning if there were big layoffs or plant closings in the near future.
Since Sept. 11, 2001, United has laid off more than 20,000 workers, or a fifth of its work force.
Unionized employees have long complained that United has too many managers on its payroll and that the airline could make its operations more efficient by laying off some of those workers. The airline is also in negotiations with its unions for short-term and long-term concessions. It is seeking interim cuts of $70 million a month from its unions and long-term cuts of $2.4 billion a year through 2008.
In a previously announced cutback, United will end service at two airports in South America and one in Germany on Tuesday, resulting in the layoffs of 183 workers. On the same day, United will also switch to regional jets instead of large planes to serve five relatively small cities in the United States, resulting in the layoffs of 150 workers. And today, United will close its reservations offices in San Francisco; Long Beach, Calif., and Indianapolis, resulting in the layoffs of 686 employees.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Ex-Merrill Analyst Notified Of Probable Fraud Lawsuit
Securities regulators have advised Henry Blodget, the former Internet stock analyst at Merrill Lynch, that he will probably be sued for fraud and other securities violations, according to someone involved in the investigation and a lawyer who has been briefed on it.
 The NASD, the largest securities regulator, objects to Mr. Blodget's public support of companies that he was deriding in e-mail messages to Merrill associates, these people say. In addition, it will argue that his research reports were inappropriately influenced by Merrill's investment bankers. Page A1. 

An End to Short New Year's Rally
A profit warning from Home Depot halted the New Year's rally on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 5.83 points, at 8,601.69. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.23 points, to 1,387.08. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 0.44 point, to 908.59. But the three key gauges ended the week with healthy gains. C4.

Bush Tax Cuts to Exceed Estimates
President Bush is expected to propose tax cuts that total significantly more than $300 billion over the next 10 years, the amount widely rumored in the last few weeks, and he wants to speed up rate reductions for the wealthiest taxpayers, White House officials said. A1.

United to Lay Off 1,500 Workers
United Airlines said it would lay off nearly 1,500 management and salaried employees by Jan. 19. That is a 14 percent reduction in its management and salaried work force, and a 1.9 percent decline over all. C2.

Jurors Were Divided in Enron Case
Jurors who were about to weigh J. P. Morgan Chase's $965 million claim against 11 insurers over Enron oil and gas trades said that they were split before the opponents in the lawsuit reached a settlement on Thursday. C2.

Heineken's Islamic World Ambitions
Heineken hopes its acquisition of Egypt's sole brewery, Al Ahram Beverages, will allow it to penetrate the Islamic world and distribute Ahram's popular Fayrouz line of nonalcoholic flavored beers. C3.

Prozac Is Approved for Children
Prozac, which is made by Eli Lilly, was approved for children and adolescents with depression, federal regulators said. C4.

Disney Sues Blockbuster Over Pact
Walt Disney has sued Blockbuster, accusing the chain of cheating its video unit of approximately $120 million under a four-year revenue-sharing agreement. C2.

Construction Spending Climbs 0.3%
The amount spent on home, hotel and highway construction increased 0.3 percent in November from the previous month after the October gain was revised up to 1 percent, the Commerce Department said. The $843.2 billion spent in November was the most since May. The lowest mortgage rates in three decades spurred record home sales. C14.

RadioShack Earnings Fall Short
RadioShack said fourth-quarter profit rose less than forecast because sales of mobile telephones and radio-controlled toys and DVD-player accessories fell short of holiday projections. Profit was 58 cents to 60 cents a share, compared with an earlier estimate of 63 cents to 68 cents, the company said. C4.

No Change Seen for British Rates
Sir Edward George, governor of the Bank of England, said he expected no "sharp change" in British interest rates, which have been 4 percent for 13 months, a 39-year low. C3.

HEADLINE: BUSH TO PROPOSE COUPLING TAX CUTS WITH AID TO STATES 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
President Bush could propose as much as $600 billion in tax cuts and new spending measures over the next 10 years, an economic stimulus package nearly twice as big as even Republican lawmakers had been expecting, administration officials said today.
 White House officials said the package, which Mr. Bush plans to outline on Tuesday in Chicago, was likely to include billions of dollars for state governments wrestling with huge budget shortfalls. 
 Officials would not provide details of the spending proposals, although they are certain to include extension of unemployment benefits. They could also include assistance for state Medicaid programs and money for improving domestic security. 
Mr. Bush may also propose tax cuts that are deeper than administration officials have been describing. One official said Mr. Bush would call for speeding up rate reductions for taxpayers at all income levels, rebutting speculation that he might slow down on reductions for people in the top tax bracket.
Mr. Bush may also push for an even bigger cut in dividend taxes than the 50 percent reduction administration officials were considering in late December.
The latest plans suggest that Mr. Bush is girding for a partisan battle with Democratic leaders in Congress, who accused him today of pursuing a misguided plan that would favor the rich and do little to help the sluggish economy.
Firing a shot even before Mr. Bush formally outlines his tax package next week, the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle, said the president's plan would be "the wrong idea at the wrong time to help the wrong people." 
Democratic lawmakers are pushing for tax breaks intended for lower- and middle-income families, with some proposing a temporary "holiday" from payroll taxes for Social Security and others proposing one-time rebates.
White House officials declined to say how big Mr. Bush's final tax proposal would be, but they suggested that the plan was, if anything, more aggressive than previously reported when it came to tax cuts for investors and people in the highest tax brackets.
Even a 50 percent reduction in dividend taxes would total about $150 billion over 10 years and would probably be the centerpiece of his tax plan. Under such a plan, the tax benefits flow almost exclusively to the very wealthiest taxpayers because they are the ones who receive most dividends.
Calculations by the Tax Policy Center, a nonprofit research group run by the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institution, show that about 64 percent of the benefits will go to the wealthiest 5 percent of taxpayers.
Administration officials acknowledge that wealthy taxpayers will be the primary beneficiaries, but they argue that reducing dividend taxes will reduce distortions in the current tax system and lift the stock market.
White House officials said Mr. Bush was also likely to propose speeding up previously scheduled rate reductions for all classes of taxpayers.
"Congress has already concluded that tax relief is necessary and has enacted it into law," said one official, alluding to income tax reductions scheduled to take effect in 2004 and 2006. "The president doesn't see any need to distinguish between groups."
Today, one day after Mr. Bush announced he would detail his plan next Tuesday, Democrats began pre-emptive attacks that concentrated heavily on what they said was the unfairness of the plan for middle-income and poorer families.
"The president's plan won't help middle-income families, it won't contribute to economic growth, it won't make our homeland more secure," said Mr. Daschle, in the text of a radio address to be delivered on Saturday.
Citing calculations by the Tax Policy Center, Mr. Daschle said that a person making more than $1 million a year would save $24,000 in taxes under Mr. Bush's plan while a person earning from $40,000 to $50,000 a year would save only $76.
Mr. Bush has already denounced such criticisms as "class warfare," though White House officials are sensitive about the issue. 
Democratic lawmakers are not the only critics. Many economists and business analysts, even those who favor the tax cuts in theory, said today that Mr. Bush's core idea of slashing dividend taxes would do little to increase economic growth or job creation.
"If you are looking for short-term stimulative effect, you don't find it there," said Hank Gutman, head of the federal tax policy practice at KMPG, the accounting firm. "All it means is that people are going to be trading their stocks more. They won't necessarily be investing any more, and companies won't have any more money to spend."
William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman Sachs, said many of the tax cuts would not even been felt until 2004, too late to provide a quick boost this year to an economy plagued by uncertainty.
"The total amount of the stimulus isn't going to be very big in 2003," Mr. Dudley said.
He added that he was assuming the tax cuts would be front-loaded to provide as much as $150 billion in relief in the first two years, but he said the actual benefits this year were likely to run from $25 billion to $50 billion, a relatively small sum in a $10 trillion economy.
White House officials insist that their plans can have a big impact and predict that the dividend tax cut will lift stock prices, improve business confidence and reduce corporations' costs of raising money.
But they acknowledge they are not greatly interested in short-term economic stimulus and disparage the idea of trying to fine-tune the economy. The real issue, they say, is improving the basis for long-term growth.
"The concern here is not over the next couple of quarters," one senior White House official said. "The concern is making sure we have the right flexibility in place to ensure the economy can grow at its full potential."
Many analysts, including those who support the Bush administration's ideas, see the tax package primarily as an effort to advance a broader philosophical agenda of overhauling the entire tax system.
Republican analysts have long argued that taxing dividends amounts to double taxation of corporate profits -- once at the corporate level and once as income to shareholders. 
The current system encourages companies to run up big debt, they argue, because interest payments are tax deductible and dividends are not. And it discourages companies from paying out dividends.
"For political reasons, they think calling it stimulus is going to resonate better than fundamental tax reform," said Joel E. Slemrod, a tax economist at the University of Michigan who supports dividend tax cuts.
Mr. Bush has been huddling with economic advisers for days at his ranch in Crawford, Tex. But Republican lawmakers and many business lobbyists say they still have little sense of many important details in the new tax proposal.
Many believe that Mr. Bush will include several measures intended for middle-income families, like a faster increase in the child-care tax credit to $1,000 from $600 and more rapid relief of the so-called marriage penalty that pushes many two-income couples into higher tax brackets.
White House officials are not interested in a reduction in the payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare. Some Democrats have argued that a holiday on payroll taxes would provide the most direct stimulus.
But Mr. Bush does plan to push for a new extension of federal unemployment benefits. The previous law expired on Dec. 28, cutting off benefits for about 750,000 people whose state-financed unemployment benefits had already run out.
